Title: Knowledge spillovers through FDI and trade and entrepreneurs' export orientation
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We draw upon the literature on knowledge spillovers to examine to what extent a country's level of foreign direct investment (both inward and outward) and international trade (export and import) influence the export orientation of its entrepreneurs. We also examine the relationship between entrepreneurs' export orientation and a country's overall level of entrepreneurial activity. We test our hypotheses using macro- level data on 34 countries covering a four-year time period (2002-2005). We find that a country's outward foreign direct investment as well as its export and import positively influence entrepreneurs' export orientation. We also find that the extent to which a country's entrepreneurs engage in export-oriented activities affects the subsequent emergence of new businesses within the country's borders. Title: Learning to acquire abroad: The role of prior experience and TMT composition
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study seeks to provide insights into the way in which organizations learn by addressing how firms decide to grow their business through international acquisitions. Specifically, we consider both behavioral and cognitive aspects of the international acquisition decision, which leads us to posit a curvilinear relationship between international acquisition experience and future acquisition activity. We also argue that this overall pattern will be moderated by demographic attributes of the top management team. Title: A taxonomy of hospital governing boards
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to develop an empirical taxonomy of governing boards in U.S. community hospitals. The taxonomy was developed using a configurational perspective and with cluster analysis according to three main areas of board responsibility-mission and strategy setting, performance evaluation and oversight, and external relations. Results of the cluster analysis were validated using ANOVA tests and discriminant analysis and were reviewed by industry experts. In a sample of 1334 community hospitals, a 5-cluster solution was identified. Assessment of the agreement between slip-half subsamples using Kappa statistic suggested that the cluster solution had high internal reliability (Kappa=0.87; p<0.0001). ANOVA tests using the entire study sample showed that the inter-cluster variance was statistically significant on the three board functions. Based on discriminant analysis, 97.5% of the hospital governing boards were determined to be correctly classified through cluster analysis, suggesting high internal validity. Systematic differences were found between clusters in terms of hospital and environmental conditions. While it is recognized that a clear goal of hospital governing boards is to build and sustain an effective hospital, our findings indicate that what boards actually do to accomplish that goal differs substantially. As the function and performance of hospital governing boards continue to receive attention, the taxonomy developed in this study would provide policy-makers, healthcareexecutives, and researchers a useful way to describe and understand the role of hospital governing boards. The taxonomy may also facilitate valid and systematic assessment of governance performance in future research.

Title: Learning during and after internationalization by entrepreneurial firms from emerging economies
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We develop and test a model that explains how entrepreneurial firms from emerging markets leam the entire internationalization process and not simply before or immediately post entry. Title: The influence of leader regulatory focus on employee creativity

Abstract: Brockner and Higgins (2001) suggest that a leader's behavior may be perceived as an organizational endorsement of promotion-focused or prevention-focused concerns and that this perception will influence employee behavior by eliciting a congruent state of regulatory focus. Title: Impact of power and relationship commitment manufacturer-customer integration in a supply chain
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Supply chain integration (SCI) has received increasing attention from academic researchers and practitioners in recent years, however, our knowledge of what influences SCI, and how SCI influences the performance of supply chains and manufacturers within the supply chain is still very limited. Although researchers in marketing and management have investigated power and relationship commitment issues within and between organizations, few have examined their impact on SCI. This paper studies the relationship between power, relationship commitment and integration between manufacturers and their customers within a supply chain. The impact of customers' SCI on the customer service and financial performance of manufacturers is also investigated. We propose and empirically test the SCI model using data collected from 617 manufacturing companies in China. The reliability and validity of the measurement instruments used in this study are also tested empirically. The results show that customers' use of different types of power has different impacts on manufacturers' relationship commitment. Expert power, referent power and reward power is very important in improving manufacturers' normative relationship commitment, while reward power and coercive power enhance instrumental relationship commitment. We also find that normative relationship commitment has a greater impact on customer integration and customer service by manufacturers than instrumental relationship commitment. Title: The human resource management practices in small private firms in China
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Ever since the open-door policy was implemented in early 1980s, the number of private small firms has been growing representing an increasingly important role in the national GDP of China (Peng, 2001). Despite many anecdotal stories about these small businesses, some reporting extraordinary successes, such as the Hope Group (Peng, 2001), others describing alarming of violations of labor laws, such as with sweat shops (Roberts & Engardio, 2006), there have been very few theoretical or empirical studies that focus on the HR practices they employ in China. Institutional theory, stakeholder theory and resource-based view are borrowed to analyze the context of the business environment of these small businesses and to frame research questions. Fifteen small firm owners in a medium-sized city in the northern part of China were interviewed, the data analyzed and a grid model developed. Results show that five firms out often in the interviewed sample are implementing quite advanced HR practices; three other firms use little or no HR efforts; the rest range in between. Some Western HR practices are in evidence, but most of the HR practices used by these small firms were developed by the owners themselves, based upon strong indigenous Chinese characteristics. Title: Substance, symbolism and the "signal strength" of venture capitalist prestige

Abstract: This study explores the symbolic and substantive benefits of VC prestige for firms that have recently completed initial public offerings (IPOs). Title: Arbiter of science: Institutionalization and status effects in fda drug review 1990-2004
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: States exert significant influence on firm outcomes and strategies through the regulation of new products. While prior research has focused on state regulation's effect on firm behavior, this paper focuses on organizational factors that influence the regulatory decision-making process. Using the approval of new drugs by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as my context, I argue that the FDA's historical evolution as an arbiter of science infused the agency with values that focus the agency's attention on specific types of signals. In particular, I contend that firm status in the knowledge domain becomes salient as the FDA attempts to resolve the uncertainty in determining drug quality. Furthermore, I propose that innovation strategies and external shocks generating uncertainty enact the FDA's scientific identity to a greater degree, rendering a firm's status in the knowledge domain even more valuable. Using the review times for 1,303 New Drug Applications (NDAs) approved by the FDA between 1990 and 2004, I find that firms with higher knowledge status receive faster approval of their drugs, with roughly a one and a half month advantage for a top 13% firm over an average firm. The benefits of being a high status actor were further enhanced when firms attempted to do radical innovation, but status had limited effects when the regulator suffered from a legitimacy crisis. Additionally, status signals of product specific competencies were less influential in expediting drug review than a firm's overall position in more broader and basic areas of knowledge. The paper concludes with a discussion of the contributions to organizational theory and the practical implications for innovative strategies of pharmaceutical and biotechnology firms.

Title: A process model of creating and out-licensing intellectual property
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper reports findings of a field study on intellectual property (IP) management at a non-profit research organization. Title: The man in the gray flannel suit in the executive suite: American corporate movies in the 1950's
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In the decade-and-a-half following the end of World War II, large, complex, corporate entities emerged as the defining institution of the American economy. Because of their size, scope, and complexity, the meaning of these newly dominant entities remained unformed to most of the American public. Management, wrote Peter Drucker in 1954, "is the least known and the least understood of our basic institutions." Most people viewed "management" as "little more than euphemism for 'the boss.'" The popular culture of the 1950s helped fill that void in understanding. Motion pictures in particular invited viewers to peak behind the closed doors of the executive suites. Between 1954 and 1960, a number of movies dealt with the complex new phenomenon of life within the giant corporation. Although produced with the goal of appealing to a large audience, motion pictures also reflected the social, political, and cultural context of the time. In particular, these movies appeared as the motion picture industry responded to the pervasive Cold War ideology that took root in the postwar years, and the public worked to reconcile a lingering distrust of big business with a newly found acceptance of and admiration for the potential for contribution for large corporations. A cycle of corporate movies produced varied between wide-eyed acceptance and exaltation of big business (Woman's World and Sabrina, for instance) and dead-end cynicism about the possibilities that giant conglomerates might offer (The Apartment). Rod Serling's Patterns occupied a complex middle space, reflecting both the possibilities and the anxieties of an economy dominated by giant corporations. This paper will examine the content of those corporate movies, with special attention to Patterns, as a way of experiencing and understanding the complex public response to the complexity of this new, dominant economic reality.

Title: I like how you think: The role of cognitive similarity as a decision bias
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We decompose the decision-making processes of a sample of venture capitalists (VCs), investigating the degree to which 'cognitive similarity' (shared patterns of reasoning between the investor and the founder) is related to the VCs' evaluations of prospective venture deals.' Employing conjoint analysis and hierarchical linear modeling techniques, we model the VCs' assessment of a series of venture deals as a function of three attributes: the economics of the opportunity, the human capital of the founder, and the reasoning patterns of the founder. We find VCs prefer to invest in founders who demonstrate patterns of reasoning similar to their own. Further, we find that when cognitive similarity is present, the relative importance of the entrepreneur's human capital becomes even more important in the VCs' assessment of the venture deal.

Title: Entrepreneurial management in the Chinese online game industry
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Due to western nations' early lead in industrialization and post-industrialization, there is a preconceived notion that the process of modernization in China is a western phenomenon. Hence, the diffusion and transfer of the modernization process necessitates a universal framework that converges on the best- practice western model. Though the recent development of new media in China - the internet - is associated with US technological innovation, its application in the context of the online game industry actually derives from elements of China's inherited cultural reality. This paper builds on existing literature in relation to national culture and business strategy to address the impact of core values upon entrepreneurial growth strategies, with reference to the Chinese online game industry. Using case study methodology, it is found that entrepreneurial Chinese online game firms diverge from the global industry leader in the USA in critical strategic areas concerning the conceptualization of firm, the appointment of top executives and the cultivation of firm culture.
Author Keywords: Chinese software; Entrepreneurial management; Online game industry
Index Keywords: Strategic planning; Business strategy; Case study methodologies; Chinese softwares; Entrepreneurial managements; ITS applications; National cultures; Online game industries; Technological innovation; Social networking (online)

Title: Advancing the measurement of organizationally directed deviance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Previous research on workplace deviance has focused almost exclusively on the antecedents and consequences of destructive or negative deviance, yet deviance can also be beneficial and violate expectations in a positive, constructive direction. Both forms of behavior are affected by policies and procedures which establish norms and expectations, yet rarely are these behaviors measured in real time. Rather, destructive and constructive deviance are often captured using self-report methodology which raises several red flags, including validity concerns, inability to assess causal relationships, and a focus on the negative to the exclusion of the positive. This field experiment focused on capturing deviance behavior in a simulated work environment, using norms prescribed for employees as the benchmark for evaluating deviance. Two hundred twenty-five individuals were employed in a one-time work opportunity where real time behavioral observations of deviance were measured. Results revealed that behavioral observations provide a valid assessment of deviance behavior, with relationships between withholding effort, performance, destructive behavior, and constructive behavior in the expected direction. Implications and directions for future research are presented.

Title: A contextual study of entrepreneur dispositional optimism: Implications for new venture performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Using a national random sample of 201 founders who were the top management team leaders of their firms, the current study examines a contextual model of entrepreneur dispositional optimism versus pessimism by evaluating its interaction with entrepreneurial experience and industry environmental dynamism on new venture performance. In dynamic environments, pessimism is found to enhance (i.e., optimism reduces) the positive relationship between entrepreneurial experience and performance. Conversely, in stable environments, optimism is found to enhance (i.e., pessimism reduces) the positive relationship of entrepreneurial experience with performance. These findings demonstrate important contextual differences in the effects of optimism versus pessimism, and suggest that recently popularized views of optimism may be oversimplified. Implication for new venture creation and development are discussed.

Index Keywords: Dynamic environments; Entrepreneurship; Environmental dynamisms; Individual Differences; New venture creation; New venture performance; New ventures; Top management teams; Human resource management

Title: The dynamics of rent creation on a strategic landscape
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The strategic entrepreneurship literature suggests that firms that adopt and develop capabilities for entrepreneurial behavior are more likely to prosper in the new competitive environment. The purpose of this study is to explore this hypothesis. This paper explicitly examines the role of various firm capabilities in the wealth creation process. In particular, this paper tests specific entrepreneurial capabilities that facilitate wealth creation under alternative configurations of the strategic landscape. We model the rent-creating processes of entrepreneurial behaviors by using agent-based simulations of the search for, and exploitation of, profitable niches in the landscape.
Author Keywords: Agent-based modeling; Dynamic capabilites; Strategic entrepreneurship

Title: THe effect of status on performance under different types of uncertainty in venture capital industry
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: I argue that the effect of status on actors' performance is higher when there is higher actor-specific uncertainty, but does not change with the level of the actors' exposure to market uncertainty. Under high actor-specific uncertainty, status and affiliation to high status actors signal the perceived quality. This certification affects resource flows, which in turn increases the actual quality and the excess performance. On the other hand, status might change actors' exposure to market uncertainty, even though it cann UNCERTA1 affect the market uncertainty itself. Therefore, once the level of exposure is controlled, the relationship between status and performance should not be moderated by the actors' exposure to market uncertainty. I test my hypotheses on the venture capital (VC) industry and find that the effect of status on VC fund's performance increases as the exposure to actor-specific uncertainty increases. On the other hand, the effect of status on the fund's performance does not change with the fund's exposure to the market uncertainty. My findings imply that investors and entrepreneurs should prefer to work with high status VC firms to gain higher returns. Furthermore, VCs can improve their performance by extending their ties and, hence, attaining more prestigious positions in the syndicate networks.

Title: The effects of employee mobility between competitors and cooperators on firm performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper builds upon traditional resource based view (RBV) perspectives of the relationship between human assets and firm performance by developing theoretical predictions based on the social capital impacts of interorganizational employee mobility. Specifically, we explore how the movement of employees between competitors and potential cooperators (in client-supplier relationships) affects the external social capital shared by focal firms with specific clients. In addition, we argue that losing employees to competitors will generally be more deleterious to the performance of firms relative to employee turnover to other destinations. We test our theories with a unique dataset of patent attorney movements between patent law firms and Fortune 500 companies, and examine how employee mobility of different types influences law firm performance. Our results show that when a focal law firm either hires attorneys from and/or loses attorneys to a Fortune 500 company, this increases the amount of future business the law firm receives from that client. Gaining employees from competing law firms that have a client relationship with a company has a positive influence on future business from that client, and losing attorneys to any competitor has a negative influence on law firm performance. Our findings suggest that human resource research may benefit from utilizing social capital arguments to examine the effects of different types of employee mobility on firm performance.

Title: Impacts of intrateam diversity on team performance variance: Two ways to take chances
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper explores how intrateam diversity may affect team performance by changing between-team performance variance, increasing the chances of both high and low performance outcomes. Previous studies have shown that diversity has contradicting effects, improving the amount of information available while degrading social integration. Most studies assume these opposed effects to mix in an additive way, leading to a neutral prediction. However, considering that such effects occur exclusively of one another leads one to hypothesize that diversity has a U-shaped effect on variance of performance. Empirically, a reanalysis of a business simulation with 35 separate teams confirms such effects for three demographic and two cognitive diversity variables. Furthermore, when constraints on performance exist, combining mean and variance analysis leads to improved predictions that contradict predictions based on the mean analysis only. The findings matter for organizational contexts that reward or punish extreme outcomes- therefore risk-providing, for instance, new insights for research in entrepreneurship, high-reliability organizations and population ecology.

Title: Revisioning organization development: A post-modern perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We argue that academic descriptions of Organization Development (OD) found in textbooks and most journal articles have not kept pace with innovations in OD practice. A growing body of OD practice has, explicitly or implicitly, rejected the modernist assumptions underlying traditional OD in favor of postmodern assumptions about discourse, narrative and the importance of changing conversations for changing human systems. In this paper we identify some of these new OD practices, consider how they differ from traditional OD and how they adhere to traditional OD values and principles. We offer a definition for a new, post-modern form of organization development and criteria for categorizing postmodern OD. We conclude with a call for recognizing this bifurcation in OD practice and increased scholarly attention to and research on post-modern OD.

Title: Networking as organizational response to institutional upheaval: Evidence from central Eurasia
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Drawing on institutional theory, we utilize data from over 700 firms in six Central Eurasian transition economies to examine the extent to which the institutional environment, composed of regulatory burden, governmental effectiveness, rule of law, and control of corruption, is predictive of the networking activities of firms in the region, and how the networking relationships of firms with other firms as well as with government officials can help them undertake restructuring initiatives in order to respond to the opportunities and challenges presented by an ever-changing business environment. Using hierarchical regression models to test hypotheses, our results indicate that inefficient institutions encourage firms to seek networking relationships with other firms, especially if they are smaller in size. Additionally, networking activities of firms with other firms as well as with government officials are significantly related to the level of restructuring efforts that are undertaken by firms in these transition economies. Young and private firms are especially more likely to leverage their networking relationship with other firms in order to undertake restructuring initiatives. The results are discussed with respect to future research requirements in these transition economies.

Title: Gendering engineering: Professional identity formation and peer effects
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: At every step along the engineering career pipeline, women exit at rates higher than men. Studies of exits from the profession at the early credentialing stage have identified failures in forming a professional identity as an engineer to be the most consequential reason for exit - exceeding measures of performance and ability, and that cultivating an engineer identity is more difficult for women than for men. Policy recommendations addressing this disparity must be informed by an understanding of the mechanisms of professional identity formation, and how they may be gendered. Theories of role identity formation from both the macro and micro perspectives emphasize the importance of social interactions, but are ambiguous regarding the causal role of peers. This paper uses a quasi-experimental design, in the form of assigned roommates, to investigate the role of peer influence on identity formation among men and women engineering students. I find both a causal role for peers in professional identity formation and that peer influence is gendered, being less influential for women than for men. I discuss the implications of these findings for policy and future research.

Title: Coordination in the remote delivery of services
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: How do organizations coordinate interdependent activities across geographic distance? We analyze surveys of offshored processes to understand both the sources of difficulty in the remote delivery of services as well as how organizations overcome these difficulties. We find that contrary to conventional wisdom, system dependence of a process is a much greater hindrance to the offshoring service delivery than process stickiness. We also find that firms could overcome system dependence by either investing in generating common ground across locations to coordinate over interdependence. However, our findings indicate that investing in modularity or in facilitating ongoing communication across locations does not lead to coordination across geographic distance. We find differences between simple and complex processes on the use of these coordination mechanisms.

Title: Are capability-based theories of firm boundaries really distinct from transaction cost theory?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: A large literature has developed over the past 10 years or so that seeks to understand the determinants of firms' vertical boundaries. Much of this literature has treated comparative capabilities (buyers' vs. potential suppliers') as determinants that are independent of transaction costs, based on the idea that capabilities theories of the firm are distinct from the transaction cost theory of the firm. In this commentary, we argue that this approach is mistaken; that in fact, capabilities and transaction cost determinants interact with other dynamically, and that the two theories of the firm cannot be conceptually distinguished. Our argument carries important implications for theories of the firm, and for empirical research aimed at testing those theories.

Title: Individual employee voice and performance management in public services
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Periodically, the 'zone of acceptance' within which management uses its authority to direct employees' work needs to adapt to new organisational needs. This has been a major focus of performance management in British public services. The process is analysed as a form of individual level integrative bargaining. Employee voice may be very weak when new work goals and priorities are imposed unilaterally by management, but strong when consideration is given to changing needs of both parties. Examples from education and health are considered. The article concludes on the ways in which collective employee voice may reinforce individual level integrative negotiation.

Title: Fetishists, politicians and resistors: Role theory as a lens for understanding institutional actors
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: I use social constructionist role theory as a basis for better understanding the links between micro- and macro levels of analysis in institutional theory. Specifically, I propose a typology of institutional actors and their agentic behaviors that systematically integrates the different conceptions of agency incorporated into institutional theory, and that (re)introduces an affective dimension into an institutional theory of practical action. Based on this typology I develop a set of propositions which provide a micro-sociological basis for understanding some forms of institutional persistence and transformation that fall outside the explanatory scope of current institutional theory.

Title: The case of vanishing borders: A study of workplace diversity as assimilation and border control
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The central themes of this paper are organizational self-identity, based on an attempt to represent a Swedish national essence, and boundaries, created through the school's attempts to assimilate its non- Swedish students into the national essence the school strives to embody. Yet the assimilatory attempts are equally damaging to the school as they can be assumed to be to the students - life at a conceptual border disrupts the staging of Swedishness and the school's identity is split into a narrative of authenticity and a set of practices which are at a distance from the Swedish essence the school so fervently advocates.
Index Keywords: Border control; Identity; Postcoloniality; Swedishs; Workplace diversity

Title: Buffering work stressors: Is social support a double-edged sword?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Social support has been cited as one of the most effective resources to alleviate job-related stress. The purpose of this study was to investigate the moderating effect of leader social support on the stress-strain relationship. A total of 768 workers from 45 different organizations participated in the study. The results of the moderated regression analyses showed that the effect of leader social support on the stressor-strain relationship depended on source congruence. Whereas we found a reverse buffering effect for leader support on the role conflict-strain relationship we found favorable buffering effects for leader support on the physical stressors-strain relationship. These differential buffering effects did not emerge when considering co-worker support. We discuss the implications of our results for shedding light on the mixed evidence regarding the buffering effects of social support reported in prior research.

Title: Configuring the user - The case of grid computing
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: From a semiotic point of view, we observe that technologies can increasingly be "authored" or "written" by their users. However, if we are to understand processes of user-driven innovation, we need not only to consider how the user writes the technology but also how the user is configured within and through different discourses. By examining the empirical case of an emergent, not-yet stabilized technology, Grid computing, and in this methodologically supplementing typical innovations studies' retrospective design, our study aims at contributing to a more fine-grained concept of the user in organization studies by suggesting that the technological artifact as well as the user is simultaneously under recursive construction. We further suggest, and discuss implications of, the concept of "lead configuration" to supplement von Hippel's notion of "lead user".

Title: Practical compassion: Towards a critical spiritual foundation for corporate responsibility
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We argue that perspectives such as Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and Workplace Spirituality (WPS) do not go far enough in mitigating the negative consequences of organizational and managerial practices based on self-interest. We suggest an alternative framework based on the notion of practical compassion and illustrate the framework with examples. We conclude with suggestions for future research.
Index Keywords: Alternative framework; Corporate responsibility; Corporate social responsibilities (CSR); Critical; Managerial practices; Spirituality

Title: Diffusion processes in IGO networks: The case of democracy
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In this paper, I examine the network of intergovernmental organizations, or IGOs, and its impact on the diffusion of democracy around the world. I propose that IGOs facilitate this diffusion by transmitting information between their member states and by interpreting that information according to the prevailing norms in the world society, where democracy is viewed as the legitimate form of government. In my empirical analysis, I find that democracy does diffuse through IGO networks, and that the influence of democratic countries is stronger than that of undemocratic countries, providing support for the role of IGOs as facilitators of communication and interpreters of information. I conclude with a discussion of future research directions and practical implications of this research.
Index Keywords: Democracy; Diffusion process; Empirical analysis; Future research directions; Inter-governmental organization; Diffusion

Title: How firms' corporate governance characteristics affect the level of human and social capital on the board
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Broad institutional pressures have led to calls for companies to implement specific governance practices. However, given the fact that companies are responding to institutional pressure, one question that has been left unanswered is how companies' implementations of agency theory practices and reforms will actually appear to current and potential directors, and by extension, how will they affect companies' ability to attract and retain good directors? This study explicitly considers how the differences in corporate governance characteristics across firms will affect companies' ability to recruit and retain directors with high levels of human and social capital. Results indicate that higher proportions of outside directors and blockholders lead to boards with lower levels of human capital over time. Results also indicate that protective governance practices may insulate firms from losing qualified directors after being sued by shareholders.
Index Keywords: Agency theory; Blockholders; Corporate governance; Directors; Governance; Human capitals; Institutional pressures; Social capitals; Industrial management

Title: Value creation and appropriation in alliance portfolios
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Extending prior research that has stressed the value-creation effect of network resources, this study uncovers how prominent partners may undermine a firm's capacity to appropriate value from its alliance portfolio. The analysis of a comprehensive dataset of 367 software firms and their 20,779 alliances suggests that the contribution of network resources to value creation varies with their complementarity. Furthermore, the relative bargaining power of partners in the alliance portfolio constrains the firm's appropriation capacity, especially when these partners compete in the focal firm's industry. In turn, the firm's market performance improves with the intensity of competition among its partners. These findings advance network research by highlighting the tradeoffs that alliance portfolios impose.
Index Keywords: Networks (circuits); Alliance; Intensity of competition; Market performance; Network resource; Performance; Software firms; Value creation; Commerce

Title: Utilizing use: The potential impact of customer use patterns on technology and industry evolution
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper argues that the way customers use a new technology may differ from what producers intended and thereby influences the evolution of that technology and its industry. Customers may interpret the technology differently or may adapt it to their local conditions and requirements, generating variety in how users actually deploy products. Moreover, as customers use new products, they may learn new ways of using the technology, which affects their future purchasing and deployment decisions. This paper argues that incorporating the process of customers using a technology provides a better explanation of the shifts in competition within an industry than prevailing evolutionary models do. This paper asserts that an industry's shift to cost-based competition depends upon customers converging on a more standardized use of the technology and that the competitive significance of a discontinuous technological change is not determined until its use characteristics are established. A brief discussion of the experience of U.S. manufacturers with manufacturing software from 1954 to 1996 demonstrates the workings of the model. Creative and strategic management of how customers understand and use a technology should be an important competitive factor in technology industries.

Title: Learning strategies and performance in innovation teams
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: As a means to understand learning and performance differences across teams, this study builds on recent advances in team learning research to propose and test a multi-dimensional model of team learning consisting of three learning strategies: experiential, vicarious, and contextual learning. Qualitative data from six innovation teams in one pharmaceutical firm are used to develop measures. Survey data from 43 additional innovation teams in six other pharmaceutical firms are used, first, to test the measurement model using structural equation modeling, and second, to test the relationships between learning strategies and team performance using random effects regression models. The paper argues that a multi-dimensional view of team learning can help us better understand how teams learn and what makes teams and organizations effective.

Title: Structural complexity and diversification
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study investigates the role of organization structure in accommodating firms diversification strategies. Based on data of organizational structure of U.S. multi-segment firms from 1993 to 2003, we find that, pure players have fewer administrative layers in their hierarchical structure if they operate in a more competitive segment. On the other hand, competitiveness does not impact diversified firmsi firms organization structure. Rather, diversified firms have more administrative layers if they operate in more heterogeneous or vertically interdependent segments. The results are consistent with theories that point to structure as a design tool to achieve better adaptation and coordination through delegation.

Title: Intra-firm knowledge flows: Explaining subsidiary isolation and its performance implications
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Applying a new theoretical and empirical approach to intra-firm knowledge transfers, this paper provides some initial insight to the little-researched phenomenon of why some subsidiaries are isolated from knowledge transfer activities within the multinational corporation. Knowledge transfer is framed as a problemistic search process initiated by the recipient unit. We show that knowledge flows from units that are perceived to be highly capable to units that perceive themselves to be highly capable. Knowledge flows are also associated with existing levels of communication and reciprocity. Taken together, these findings suggest that knowledge transfers in MNCs typically occur between highly capable members of an in-crowd, while the isolated minority rarely, if ever, engage in knowledge sharing activities. Finally, we show that the isolated minority underperforms other subsidiaries, suggesting the possibility of a liability of internal isolation".

Title: Boundary constructions in interorganizational knowledge relations
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In the wake of the "knowledge society" organizations are becoming increasingly dependent on external knowledge sources. Consultants, networks, alliances, etc. are all increasingly important ways through which organizations secure access to central knowledge. This paper sets out to investigate interorganizational knowledge relations by asking the question "How do people involved in interorganizational knowledge work construct boundaries within and around their knowledge intensive endeavours?" Based on an interview study we identify different kinds of knowledge relations. An analysis of the accounts of these relations points at five dimensions along which boundaries are constructed - interests, interpretive frameworks, trust, private/organizational and priority. Based on these dimensions and the social-interaction perspective theoretically underpinning the paper a dynamic model for understanding boundary construction in interorganizational knowledge work is suggested.

Title: When confidence comes too soon: Collective efficacy, conflict and group performance over time
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Groups with a strong sense of collective efficacy set more challenging goals, persist in the face of difficulty, and are ultimately more likely to succeed than groups who do not share this belief. Given the many advantages that may accrue to groups who are confident, it would be logical to advise groups to build a strong sense of collective efficacy as early as possible. However, drawing on Whyte's (1998) theory of collective efficacy and groupthink, we argue that when confidence emerges toward the begining of a group's existence, group members may be less likely to engage in productive conflicts that are necessary to function effectively. Therefore, a strong sense of collective efficacy early in a group's existence might actually have a negative effect on group performance over time. We found support for these predictions in a longitudinal study of classroom project teams.

Title: It's the thought that counts: How managers' beliefs shape the effects of monitoring
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We argue that the effects of managerial practices can be experienced as either coercive or enabling, depending upon the intentions with which managers implement those practices. We demonstrate how the effect on subordinates of a basic managerial practice - monitoring - varies from positive to negative depending on managers' beliefs. Using a matched survey of managers and subordinates in a hightechnology engineering firm, we find evidence that monitoring reduces subordinate job satisfaction and job challenge when managers believe workers are extrinsically motivated. However, monitoring increases job satisfaction, organizational commitment and job challenge when managers believe that subordinates have low extrinsic motivation.

Title: Restructuring nurse roles in response to case mix reimbursement: A contingency approach
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Using contingency theory, we determine whether the implementation of Medicare and Medicaid case mix reimbursement increased the administrative burden on nursing homes, as evidenced by increased levels of nurses in administrative functions. Results indicate that both Medicaid case mix reimbursement and Medicare PPS increased the level of administrative nurse staffing, on average by 5.5% and 4.0% respectively. However, lack of evidence for a substitution effect suggests that any decline in direct care staffing after the introduction of case mix reimbursement is not attributable to a shift from clinical nursing resources to administrative functions.

Title: Longing to belong: Expanding the market-hierarchy-clan taxonomy to encompass new organizational types
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper draws on theories of embeddedness and knowledge to add one type - democracies - to the classic markets, hierarchies, clans framework for selecting and sorting organizational structures. This simple addition greatly expands the model's ability to make sense of the bewildering variety of organizational forms, including networks, alliances, cooperatives and open-source communities. More practically, the resulting taxonomy provides insight into the organizational forms appropriate for various environmental and resource conditions.

Title: From purpose to passivity: Tradition and knowledge in interorganizational collaboration
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: As a process, interorganizational collaboration has been argued to present many complex challenges, and these challenges are rooted in a wide range of factors. In this paper the role of one such factor, tradition, is considered in order to provide some insight on the difficulties of collaborative processes. The role of tradition in collaboration is considered in connection with knowledge, in relation to two established areas of extant research. Firstly, a body of work addressing tradition and knowledge describes the persistence of tradition as a basis for interpretation and thus its connection with the constitution of knowledge. Secondly, established literature focussed upon collaboration and knowledge conceptualizes interorganizational collaborations as sites of potentially conflicting understandings and interpretations of knowledge. However, there is no extant research that investigates the overlaps and linkages between these two areas. It is this gap that the current paper addresses, through qualitative research in three collaborative situations; insights about the modes of carriage of tradition in knowledge, in collaborative contexts, are derived and implications for the process of collaboration are discussed.

Title: Variation through replication: The extent and sources of variance when replicating organizational routines
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The replication of knowledge embedded in organizational routines is increasingly seen as critical to the competitive advantage of firms in a variety of industries. However, replication, as a strategy for exploiting firm knowledge assets is problematic as repeated exploitation may lead to competency traps, organizational inertia, and an inability to adapt critical knowledge to changing environmental conditions. Many firms that compete through replication, however, appear to be vibrant over long periods of time suggesting that mechanisms for change, even in the face of intense exploitation, may exist. This paper addresses the problem by asking two questions-to what extent do we observe variation in firms that compete through replication and what are the sources of that variation. The sample includes monthly indicators of variation in fundamental routines for a census of all U.S. units of a large franchise organization in the service sector over an 11 year period operating. We describe the data by partitioning variation into center led, inter-temporal, within-unit, inter-temporal, and between-unit, geographic variation and using Hierarchical Linear Modeling to test for a variety of potential antecedents.

Title: Consultants to the rescue? Antecedents and consequences of hiring consultants during the startup process
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper examines the conditions under which founders are likely to seek outside consulting assistance and the implications for firm performance of such assistance. Using a sample of new startups in the U.S. banking industry, we find that environmental complexity and regulatory change are influential factors in a founder's decision to hire a consultant. Moreover, we find that consultants have a positive impact on a measure of firm financial performance, but no impact on a more comprehensive composite measure of performance. Finally, post hoc analyses show that while the effectiveness of outside consulting assistance depends on the individual consulting firm, it is not necessarily a function of the consulting firm's cumulative experience of similar engagements.

Title: The complementary effects of relational dissimilarity and group faultlines: A multi-level analysis of diversity
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Relational and team diversity studies typically measure demographic differences that may impact team members' ability to work and perform well together. Euclidian distance and Blau's (1977) measures tend to ignore the context in which differences occur and the pattern of (dis)similarities that occur across multiple dimensions within the team. This study attempts to address this issue by using multiple measures of diversity, linking them together through hierarchical linear modeling.

Title: Investment in permanent employees and exchange perceptions among temporary employees
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study investigated the mediating roles of social and economic exchange perceptions on the relationship between perceived investment in employee development in the client organization and exchange outcomes among 375 temporary employees. The results of our study support full mediation by exchange perceptions, where social exchange perceptions is positively related to both task performance and organizational citizenship behavior and economic exchange perception is negatively related to task performance. Implications for practice and directions for future research are discussed.

Title: Replication and adaptation: The effect of adaptation degree and timing on the performance of replicated routines
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In terms of gaining competitive advantage knowledge assets are widely considered to be the most critical firm resources. For many firms, because of the difficulty in imitating them, the most important knowledge assets are those embedded in organizational routines. And a growing body of scholarship suggests that competitive advantage is directly related to a firm's ability to leverage that knowledge by replicating it throughout the firm. One of the critical considerations in replication is the effect of adaptation on the performance of transferred routines. A long standing tradition in a variety of literatures suggests that transferred assets in general should be adapted as soon as possible to increase fit with the local environment. More recent research on replication, however, suggests that adaptation may have negative side effects with fit with the original template and fit within a system of units with similar routines also important considerations. This paper addresses two moderating factors, extent and timing of adaptation, which may offer a rapprochement. To test these effects we utilize a unique dataset involving monthly performance data and two types of adaptation indicators, the addition of new routines and the modification of existing ones, for a majority of the U.S. units (approx. 3,500) of a large non-food franchisor over an 11 year period. Utilizing panel data methods we test for the significance of both moderators and measure the effect of different levels of adaptation versus a baseline of non-adaptation over time. The analyses indicate strong effects for both extent and timing of adaptation.

Title: The mediating role of bank knowledge in small and new firm access to debt finance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Using a matched sample of 1,677 responses from small-firm executives collected from the National Foundation of Independent Business (Scott, Dunkelberg & Dennis, Jr., 2003), we examine the direct and mediating role of a bank's knowledge about firms on those firms' access to debt finance. Specifically, we examine how firm size and bank organizational structure influence knowledge and thereby influence a firm's access to credit. Findings suggest that firm size is positively associated with a bank's knowledge about a firm, while the degree of a bank's mechanistic structure is negatively associated with a bank's knowledge about a firm. Knowledge fully mediates the relationship between firm size and bank organizational structure on a firm's access to credit.
Index Keywords: Finance; Firm size; Knowledge; Mediating roles; Organizational structures; Small firm; Knowledge management

Title: Utrinque paratus[1]: A case study of discourse and identity in the British parachute regiment
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper analyzes how participants' preferred conceptions of their selves are disciplined by the A CA5E organizationally-based discursive and material resources on which they draw. Our paper is principally an in-depth case study of the subjectivities of men who were serving, or who had served, in an elite military unit - the British Parachute Regiment. In examining issues of agency and control in identity matters we employ literature on subjectivity, the discursive construction of identity, the self as a project, and identity regulation. There is a dearth of research in management studies on military institutions, and one important element of the research contribution of this paper is to explore issues of subjectivity and identity regulation in these under-explored work organizations. Two aspects of our case are particularly highlighted. First, we argue that soldiers' evolving self-conceptions were disciplined not (just) by anxieties but by understandings of themselves as professionally tough, and their continuous aspiration to be more authentic paratroopers. Second, rather than focus on how those who were hierarchically privileged sought to manipulate discursive resources for their own ends, we examine a range of paratroopers, to illustrate how all (officers and enlisted men) were subject to, and constituted by, the material and discursive practices of the Regiment.
Index Keywords: Discourse; Identity; Material resources; Military; Military units; Work organization; Parachutes

Title: Towards a typology of stakeholder management strategies
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper offers a theoretical typology of stakeholder management strategies that firms may adopt when making choices about managing stakeholder relationships. We use the stakeholder relationship or contract as the unit of analysis and describe stakeholder management strategies based on two dimensions: ex ante search behaviors (exploration and exploitation) and ex post response processes (proactive and reactive). Four stakeholder management strategies are proposed: proactive explorer, proactive exploiter, reactive explorer, and reactive exploiter. In addition, propositions are offered to address the performance implications of these strategies and the conditions under which strategies are adopted by firms.
Index Keywords: Ex antes; Exploration and exploitation; Response process; Search behavior; Stakeholder management strategy; Two-dimension; Unit of analysis

Title: Kurt lewin's promise and choiceful consulting
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Kurt Lewin (1890 - 1947) understood change and development. As an immigrant to the U.S. and escapee of Nazism, he understood the importance of tolerance and social justice. Sixty years have passed since his untimely death; his contributions are practiced in management consulting everyday globally. In the face of war, bigotry and injustice his research was grounded in democratic values, reflective observation, action research and field theory. He was an imminent scholar, teacher and practitioner who mentored many great contributors to the field of applied behavioral science. His humanitarian work and innovative ideas continue to influence the development of the field of applied behavioral sciences across a broad array of institutions, settings and methodologies. They contribute to improving quality of life and productivity of groups, organizations and institutions. The emerging dynamic management consultancy provides opportunities for furthering Lewin's contributions. The new technologies, global competition, wars, widening division of haves and have-nots, the misuse of natural resources and global warming, and growing interdependence of world events are changing human life experience in multitude of ways. Lewin's work offers a promise to a deeper understanding of the appropriateness of prevailing values, paradigms, purposes and approaches to change and development. Two future choices are developed. One deals with approaches dominated by economic and competitive values. The other extends the humanitarian and developmental values and aspects of Lewin work. The paper outlines the nature, characteristics, and merits of the two approaches in a world of change and opportunities.
Index Keywords: Global warming; Behavioral science; Change; Consulting; Dynamic management; Global; Global competition; Innovative ideas; Management consulting; Behavioral research

Title: Strategic adaptation during institutional transition
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We link agency theory and an institutional theory to predict the strategic choices firms make during a period of institutional transition. The strategic choices we investigate are the choice to exit the market, and the choice to collaborate with foreign firms. We investigate the impact of ownership concentration, ownership identity, business group affiliation and institutional transition on these strategic choices. The results based on a longitudinal sample of more than 9000 Indian firms during 1990-2005 suggest that different owners have different motivation and preferences in making the strategic choices. We also find a significant variation in firms' strategic choices during different phases of institutional transition and for group affiliated and un-affiliated firms.
Author Keywords: Business groups; Institutional transition; Strategic choices
Index Keywords: Agency theory; Business groups; Foreign firms; Indian firms; Institutional theory; Institutional transition; Strategic adaptations; Strategic choice

Title: The dual processes of team leadership: A multilevel perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: One under-researched area in the team literature is team leadership or how a team leader influences an aggregate of members and integrates collective efforts to achieve desired outcomes. To fill in this void, we proposed a model incorporating dual leadership processes at two conceptual levels (between-unit and within-unit levels) articulating how team leaders' transformational leadership behaviors (team-focused and individual-focused) impact team effectiveness through members' cognitive reactions (self-identification) and perceptions (efficacy beliefs). We tested the model using a field sample consisting of 70 teams with 70 leaders and 573 members from eight different organizations. Results from the structural equation modeling analyses supported all seven hypotheses. Findings from the current study contribute to the literatures on team leadership, transformational leadership, and multilevel leadership. Implications for managerial practices are discussed.

Title: Working together, bowling alone: The organizational roots of civic decline
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Political scientists and sociologists have spent the past decade puzzling over declining civic engagement in the United States. Management scholars who study interactions between organizations and their stakeholders have much to contribute to this debate. This paper addresses the relationship between the exercise of authority in organization-stakeholder interactions and macro-social trends in civic and political behavior. I propose that changes in these authority patterns may account for historical trends and regional differences in civic engagement.

Index Keywords: Civic engagement; Historical trends; Political behaviors; Regional differences; Social issues; Social trend; Stakeholder theory

Title: Neutrality, categorization, and the evolvability of organizations
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The evolutionary sciences have served as a useful reservoir of ideas for studies of adaptation by organizations. Adaptation proceeds by incremental organizational changes that either improve or worsen an organizations fit to its environment. Studies in this line of research often show organizations as prone to competency traps from which they are unable to exit. We posit that given such suboptimality, it is in the evolutionary advantage of organizations adaptively to evolve a capability that, though limited, can avoid deadend traps. This capability is the categorization of knowledge which permits a firm to be 'neutral' to small fitness changes that result from incremental change. We employ the concept of neutrality into an NK model of adaptive search. Organizations engaged in neutral search achieve better performance outcomes compared to those that do not, and benefit from higher survival chances. These results indicate that inertia has adaptive value, explaining why curtailing entrepreneurship may be in an organization's interest.

Title: Home-country networks, intangible assets, and foreign expansion
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We propose that network position in the home country constitutes an intangible asset that shapes the pattern of international expansion of the firm but only if it is transferable to other countries. We argue that social status is transferable as a signal of quality or worth, while brokerage advantage is less so. Accordingly, we predict that companies pursue more opportunities in foreign markets as their social status grows and their brokerage advantage falls. We also argue that the greater the status of the company, the more it prefers foreign markets with less uncertainty so as to minimize the possibility of expropriation of their status advantage. Using data on the syndication experience and market entries of 1,010 American venture capital firms over the 1990-2002 period, we find robust support for our predictions.
Index Keywords: Expansion; Investments; Social networking (online); Foreign market entries; Foreign markets; Intangible assets; International expansion; Market entry; Social status; Venture capital firms; Commerce

Title: Putting the organization back into computational organization theory: A multiple-perspective model
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: At best, computational models that study organizations incorporate only one perspective of how organizations are known to act within their environments. Such single-perspective models are limited in their generalizability and applicability to the real world and allow for researcher bias. This work develops a multiple agent-based simulation using 8 different perspectives that are common in organization studies: Institutional theory, behavioral decision theory, enactment, strategic choice, resource dependence, contingency theory, transaction cost economics, and population ecology. A literature review of each field is applied to the construction of algorithms which, when combined with a literature review of computational modeling techniques, was applied to the construction of a series of algorithms describing a multi-perspective computational model. Computer code was written based on the algorithms and run across different types of environments. Results were studied with an emphasis on model validiy, and some conclusions were made with regard to the behavior of organizations and the model's applicability toward further research.

Title: Inter-subsidiary collaboration for knowledge: A conceptual model
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: A growing body of recent research on multinational corporations emphasizes the role of subsidiaries in creating and sharing knowledge and the importance of viewing a MNC as a differentiated network. A key premise of this literature is that various units of the MNC are inter-connected in a web of relationships or a network, which makes it possible for knowledge to flow from one part of the MNC to another. While ties among subsidiaries-the key players of a MNC network-are a prerequisite for the formation of the network and the flow of knowledge, we know little about factors influencing the formation of such ties. By building on the literature on knowledge based view and inter-firm networks, we identify and discuss factors influencing the formation of knowledge ties among subsidiaries and the effectiveness of the ties in knowledge flow. Our multi-level conceptual model incorporates subsidiary characteristics, inter-subsidiary forces, and contextual factors in inter-subsidiary tie formation and the effectiveness of the ties in facilitating knowledge flow. This paper advances our understanding of the central role played by subsidiaries in the MNC network and has several important implications for future research and management practice.

Title: The effects of entrepreneur abusive supervision
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study examines the effects of abusive supervision by new venture top management team leaders on the organizational citizenship behavior (i.e., social loafing, teamwork, altruism, and courtesy) of their executive teams and the performance of their startups (i.e., employment and revenue growth). Further, the moderating effect of perceived environmental uncertainty on these relationships is also considered. Using a sample of executive teams from 342 different new ventures, abusive supervision is found to be negatively related to both executive team organizational citizenship behavior and firm performance. These relationships are, however, founded to be significantly less negative under conditions of high perceived environmental uncertainty. Implications for theory, research, and practice are discussed.
Index Keywords: Entrepreneurship; Firm Performance; Leadership; Moderating effect; New ventures; Organizational citizenship behaviors; Perceived environmental uncertainty; Top management teams; Human resource management

Title: Focusing on lone trees in the forest: Members' experiences of a multiple identity organization
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper examines the impact of multiple organizational identities on lower-level organization members. Building on existing research about the management of multiple identity organizations, we report results from a longitudinal field study of lower-level members of a multiple identity organization. Using interview data, archival data, and longitudinal survey data, we detail the interplay between identities and identification in a non-profit organization, showing that lower-level members tend to limit their focus and connection to a single identity of the organization, potentially derailing the outcomes that the organization aims to achieve. The distinct experience of lower-level members - focused identification - suggests new boundary conditions for the validity of the multiple identity construct.
Index Keywords: Identification (control systems); Archival data; Civic volunteering; Longitudinal field study; Longitudinal surveys; Multiple identities; Non profit organizations; Organizational identities; Nonprofit organization

Title: 'Similar, yet distinct': The influence of categorical properties on entry in film production
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Theorization within sociological and organizational literature suggests that recognition of a category is driven to a large degree by two fundamental properties: the similarity of producers within the category and the distinctiveness of the category relative to others in the market. However, the specific ways in which similarity and distinctiveness influence categorical understandings, and thus market behavior, remain theoretically underspecified. In this paper, we advance knowledge of the cognitive processes underlying market evolution by investigating the impact of these two properties on a core determinant of the vitality of categories-new entries by producers. We propose that similarity and distinctiveness work in discrete ways to guide entry rates. Similarity of producers within a category allows for the development of clear categorical understandings, facilitating coordination and mobilization of the resources necessary for organizing. Distinctiveness, by contrast, increases the salience of a category vis--vis other producers, helping categories to attract attention from market participants. For both properties, we propose threshold effects such that very high levels of similarity and distinctiveness work to depress entry rates. We find support for our propositions using data on the entry of U.S. production companies into feature film genres during the period 1914-1970.

Title: Economic pressure and the deterioration of research ethics
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Almost no day goes by without news about unethical, misbehaving managers, sportsmen, or politicians that sought personal profit by exploiting third parties, by tricking the public, and by breaking explicit and implict rules and norms. Rather than exclusively calling criminal individuals to account for cheating, we suggest that tournament like, winners-take-all contexts along with low risks of being disclosed play an important role. As competition within academia has soared on various levels, the paper suggests that incentives for academic misconduct have been increased, too. Referring to calls for more extensive reflections about motivations for cheating costs and benefits of academic honesty versus misconduct in this context are analyzed. We suggest that these shape the incentives for rational, self-interested individuals to act honestly or dishonestly when conducting and reporting academic research. We develop propositions to test our hypothesis in the future and outline promising avenues for research and academic practice to maintain the high level of research ethics we all depend on.

Title: Alliance activity as a dynamic capability: Search and internalization of external technology
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Previous research has often seen alliances as a mechanism used by disadvantaged firms to seek new capabilities. But are alliances an effective dynamic capability? We find that less competent firms can use alliances to access new technologies, but more competent firms are superior in internalizing new capabilities from their alliances.

Title: Integrating job stress and social exchange theories to predict employee wellbeing
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This research examines the organizational characteristics that contribute to employee wellbeing in public sector agencies that have undergone substantial organizational change. Two studies were undertaken, the first involving 2466 police officers working in a state-based law enforcement agency, while the second comprised 1010 occupationally-diverse employees working in a State Government authority. The research was guided by a theoretical framework that begins with a model underpinning many large-scale job stress investigations - the job strain model (JSM) - and is expanded to incorporate psychological contract breach and organizational fairness theory. The results of hierarchical regression analyses from both studies confirm the value of the JSM. There was also strong support for extending the JSM to include the breach and fairness variables. The practical implications of these results, particularly for organizations that have undergone extensive organizational reforms, are discussed.

Title: Second acts: Exploring the postacquisition mobility of acquiring and target CEOS
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Research over the past three decades strongly established that top managers of target firms disproportionately leave after mergers or acquisitions, while research over the same time period virtually ignored the departures of top managers from the acquiring side. Regardless of the acquirer or target affiliation of the manager, career trajectories beyond the binary outcome of stay or go were little explored. Through analysis of a sample of large turn-of-the-millennium M&A deals, the present study complements the existing literature by addressing the extended post-M&A mobility of CEOs from both the acquiring and target sides from a theoretical vantage emphasizing mobility considerations in the context of status and stratification. The study finds that departure from the merged organization does not preclude continued career achievements for either type of CEO. Whether CEOs leave willingly or unwillingly, they continue to have prestigious prospects, and target CEOs are more likely than acquirers to resurface in top leadership positions comparable to the ones they left.

Title: Development and validation of a multidimensional scale of entrepreneurial risk perception
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Entrepreneurship is a multidimensional phenomenon and yet as scholars, we continually use unidimensional measures in many areas of our research to capture and assess our own beliefs, hypotheses, and models of entrepreneurial behavior. For example, our own measures of risk have relied on only one underlying assessment and measurement of how entrepreneurs perceive risk as it relates to their own judgments and decisions regarding the new venture creation process Our current research presents the development and validation of a multidimensional measure designed to assess the perceived risk associated with entrepreneurial venture intentions. We report analyses of both the internal construct development and cross-structure of a new scale. On the internal construct development side, two meta-dimensions emerged: risk as threat and risk as opportunity, each one representing financial, social, and personal dimensions. On the external side, we show the usefulness of considering these two types of perceived risk in models of entrepreneurial intentions and decision making.

Title: Reconciling family-centric and professionalized governance: Boards of firms within family business groups
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We examine the antecedents of board composition in firms that constitute family business groups (FBGs), increasingly recognized as a generic organizational form that is dominant within the economies of many late-industrializing countries. In a study on 299 group firms affiliated to 10 FBGs in Turkey, we compare predictions derived from contingency and socio-political perspectives on board formation. Our results provide greater support for the latter perspective, showing that, relative to contingencies facing group firms, institutional pressures and the presence of powerful external parties better predict board composition within the context of FBGs.
