Title: Long-term brokerage: Relationship duration and returns to brokerage in the staffing sector
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: While much research shows that individuals and organizations that bridge previously unconnected actors obtain superior economic advantages, little work has addressed how such benefits from brokerage evolve over time. Existing theory assumes that the returns to brokerage should be short-lived. We argue by contrast that, in markets with high information asymmetry, the returns to brokerage may actually increase over time. We use fieldwork and quantitative data from the staffing sector to examine how the duration of the relationship between market brokers and the brokered parties, as well as between the brokered parties themselves, affects the returns to brokerage. We test our hypotheses using information on relationships, bill rates, and margins from a broker in this market - a specialized temporary help agency. Our results show that long term relationships between the agency and the workers (i.e., the "brokered party") increase both bill rate and percentage commission. Long term ties between the worker and the client firms, however, reduce the bill rate and commission. These findings demonstrate the importance of long-term relationships in brokerage, and have more general implications for the understanding of how positional advantages are sustained over time.

Title: Towards a practice-based approach to institutional change: Institutional change and structuration theory's neglected praxeological aspects
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: With the shifting research focus from issues of isomorphic to ongoing institutional change, institutionalism is faced with several theoretical challenges that until now remain unresolved: How do we conceptualize institutions in a way that acknowledges their character as historical phenomena open to change within the course of ongoing social processes? How can we account for actors' abilities towards institutions without overemphasizing their role? And how do we conceptually grasp the linkage between ongoing actions on the micro level and institutions usually regarded as macro-level phenomena? This article claims that these challenges cannot be resolved without overcoming the ontological struggle that lies behind them: the struggle between holism and individualism. It is the general purpose of this article to raise the awareness for an alternative approach towards institutional change which is grounded on practice theories. Practice theories are a promising means in that they generally aim at overcoming the ontological struggle. Their contribution to a processual and balanced account of institutional change is discussed with reference to selected praxeological concepts of structuration theory that has been neglected so far. Overall, this article provides reasoning and conceptual guidance for a practice-based account of institutional change that contributes to issues of processualism, agency, and micro-macro linkage.

Title: How do entrepreneurs attract (high valuation from) outsiders? Integrating real-world practices and economic theory to understand entrepreneurs' actions
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper weds entrepreneurial practice and economic theory to address the question: How do entrepreneurs attract (high valuation from) outsiders? To that end, we identify four characteristics common across different entrepreneurial setting (i.e., information asymmetries, weak patents, limited wealth, and optimism) and discuss their effect on two popular entrepreneurial actions. These actions are (a) exposure of the invention (Disclosure), or (b) a Contingent Payment Scheme (CPS) offer (e.g., royalty based license, deferral of pay). Outsiders infer invention's quality indirectly from entrepreneur's CPS choice, or asses it directly by inspecting disclosed information. Because wary outsiders cannot inspect the invention when presented with a CPS, they discount the valuation in lieu of potential entrepreneurial optimism. Disclosure, hence, might offer higher valuation. But once information is disclosed, the outsider has in effect acquired the invention without cost. Disclosure, thus, is costly due to weak patents and potential imitation. Using a formal model that allows for clear definitions and parsimonious analysis of each action's costs and benefits, we then answer the opening question.

Title: Satisficing signaling: Corporate social strategy and certified management standards
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We develop a framework of satisficing signaling to explain corporate use of certified management standards (CMS) that enhance social welfare. Previous research has likened CMS to signaling mechanisms and consequently applied signaling theory to their analysis. Yet empirical data indicates an incomplete match between this theory and the actual functioning of CMS. Using the example of an environmental CMS we propose that contrary to the predictions of signaling theory plants with poor environmental performance adopt a CMS. These plants are however superior performers when compared to other plants within multi-plant firms. We use ISO 14001 data to test predicted adoption patterns.

Title: In the eyes of the follower: Construction of charisma in response to organizational change
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Taking a follower-centric perspective, we examined how charisma was constructed differently by organizational members as they responded to organizational change. We proposed that attributed charisma of a change leader varies due to differences in self-interest and emotion and that charisma construction also differs across constituent groups. Three semi-experimental studies examined how college business students and executive MBA students responded to grading policy reform aimed at reducing grade inflation. Results supported the majority of our hypotheses. We discuss directions for future follower-centric leadership research on charisma construction.

Title: Cultivating taste: Constructing the importance of product aesthetics in technological industries
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In this theory development case study, I argue that firms address the challenges of competition in standardized technological environments by engaging in technological and well as non-technological innovations, those based on aesthetic design components that have a symbolic effect rather than an instrumental purpose. More specifically, this study examines the emergence of a competitive logic centered on using aesthetic product elements to manipulate the consumption of technological goods. I study this emergence in the context of a standardized and commoditized high-technology industry-the US personal computer industry. I conduct a computer-aided text analysis of product reviews as well as an analysis of pictures of personal computers during a period of incremental technological innovation dominated by cost-driven competition, 1992-2003. Based on the analyses, I suggest that firms construct their constituents' taste for products with unique aesthetic features to mitigate the competitive difficulties of their environments.

Title: The impact of mood and emotion on risk preference
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We propose to use affect research to enrich the dominant descriptive model of risk preference, prospect theory (Kahneman, & Tversky, 1979). We will pursue a discussion of 1) the mood's direct impact on probabilities, 2) the contrast effect between mood and anticipated emotion on perceived values, and 3) combined impacts. Finally, we will discuss the managerial implications of this theory.

Title: The myth of modern management: Roman and antebellum management ideology in comparative perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Drawing on archival materials from the Roman Republic and U.S. antebellum South, this paper questions narratives that place the origins of administrative theory in late 19th or early 20th century industrial society. Agrarian societies based on chattel slavery relied on an extensive corps of supervisors and devoted considerable effort to discourse surrounding the management of unfree labor. Following Bendix, we seek to understand management theories in these societies as ideologies, rooted in ideas that justify the authority of landowners and defend their organizations against legitimacy crises. Based on a systematic review of documents from Roman and Southern writers, we argue that the distinctive political challenges in each historical case led to divergent management ideologies, despite a common economic basis in agricultural enterprise employing gang-system slave labor. In the late Roman Republic and early empire, management ideology confronted challenges to large-scale landownership and absentee landlords. In the antebellum South following the Nat Turner revolt, management thinkers staved off threats from abolitionism and Northern political activists. We conclude by asking why the managerial belief systems in these agrarian societies have largely been ignored by subsequent organizational scholars, including research on the history of management.

Title: Team personality composition, collective personality, and team effectiveness
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We explore the connections between team personality composition, collective personality, and team effectiveness drawing from Chan's (1998) framework of composition models and Hofmann and Jones's (2005) concept of collective personality. We suggest that team personality composition in terms of the Five Factor Model of personality (Costa & McRae, 1992; Hogan, 1991) may be an important antecedent of collective personality. We then consider the impact collective personality has on team effectiveness (satisfaction, viability, perceived performance, and objective performance). Based on a sample of 278 participants in 37 student teams, our findings indicated that three of five team personality composition antecedents are positively related to their respective collective personality dimension counterparts (in the cases of Extraversion, Emotional Stability, and Openness to Experience). Also, all five dimensions of collective personality were found to be positively related to at least one of the four aspects of team effectiveness.

Title: Falling flat: Failed technologies and investment under uncertainty
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: How do suppliers capture the value they create with their clients? In this paper, I empirically examine the role of two drivers of suppliers' value capture for supplier profitability and buyer-supplier relationship stability. The first driver is the distinctiveness of suppliers' expertise compared to what their clients can get from competitors. The second driver is the realization of client-based scope economies through cross-selling. I analyze a unique longitudinal data set from the UK corporate legal market that comprises the client relationships of the largest UK law firms with FTSE 250 corporations, experts' assessment of law firms' capabilities, and law firms' profitability. I find that superior expertise relative to direct competitors and cross-selling, both by a focal firm and by its competitors, are important drivers of supplier profitability and client relationship stability. Moreover, cross-selling appears to be an important source of differentiation that also has a direct impact on competitors' ability to capture value. Overall, these findings contribute to our understanding of how competition and firm heterogeneity interplay to affect firm performance.

Title: The paradoxes of learning from failures
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Drawing on and extending the research on escalation of commitment and organizational learning, this paper intends to elaborate upon inherent difficulties of learning from relatively large failures. We introduce the paradox of learning from failures, which explains unexpected outcomes when learning from failures is purposefully sought. We propose three such paradoxes: escalation paradox, repetition paradox, and defensive paradox.
Index Keywords: Commitment; Escalation of commitments; Learning from failures; Organizational learning; Paradoxes

Title: Extreme events, power laws, and adaptation: Towards an econophysics of organization
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Managers are often required to respond in adaptive ways to the threats and opportunities presented by rare, extreme events. In turn, organizational scholars face a stark choice: Say something useful to practitioners using narrative stories in which dramatic effects are achieved at the expense of academic rigor or maintain academic integrity by sacrificing practitioner relevance. Organization science needs find a way to study extremes more rigorously. For a new perspective, we turn to an emerging new physics expressly aimed at dealing with complexity dynamics. Econophysics is the name given to the application of this new physics to economic problems. It incorporates biological concepts of organization, ones in which organization becomes an attribute of the elements of a group or aggregation in interaction-an emergent property of the aggregation's internal connectivity. The paper draws on a different method of understanding and dealing with complex phenomena. It distinguishes between the old simplicity of reductionism, equations, linearity and predictions of old physics, and the new simplicity of insignificant initiating "butterfly-events"-nonlinearity, similar causal dynamics at multiple levels, power laws, and scale-free theory. Cognitive representations of the real-world and follow-on creation of response schema are shifted from Gaussian simplicity to Paretian simplicity. Organizational schema formation and adaptation within the Gaussian and Paretian ontologies are framed in terms of adaptive responses subject to Ashby's Law of Requisite Variety. We show how the variety perceived to be requisite is sensitive to the type of ontological assumptions that are made and examine how this affects an agent's social information processing strategies and schema formation. An organization science based on researching scale-free dynamics and fractal structures is outlined.
Index Keywords: Ontology; Academic integrity; Econophysicss; Extremes; Fractal structures; Internal connectivity; Organization science; Power-law; Social information processing; Dynamics

Title: Vertical integration over the industry lifecycle: Evidence from the early U.S. auto industry
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Even though vertical integration choices have been found to significantly affect firm performance, There has been little empirical study of how such choices are affected by the stage of industry evolution in which firm's find themselves. Combining theories of industry evolution with transaction cost theory, we empirical investigate three possible impacts of the industry lifecycle on firm's vertical integration choices. First, we hypothesize that the emergence of a dominant design is associated with vertical disintegration because of the standardization of components that dominant designs tend to promote. Second, we posit that firms selling at higher price points, because they are attempting to differentiate their products by incorporating unique components, will tend to be more vertically integrated than their lower-price rivals. Finally, we hypothesize that firms with more early production experience, because they tend to develop superior production capability relative to suppliers, will tend to be more vertically integrated into components. We find evidence for all three effects in data from the early U.S. auto industry. We draw implications for organizational modularity and for endogenizing transaction costs.

Title: F-PEC scale of family influence: A refinement
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study provides further examination of the validity and reliability of the family influence scale presented by Klein, Astrachan, and Smyrnios (2005). Data from 831 family businesses were analyzed to assess the measure's construct validity. Using exploratory and confirmatory techniques, a model emerged that included three hypothesized factors, namely, culture, power, and experience. Extending the previous effort, the measure's convergent validity was tested by assessing differences between the measure's scores and (a) the desires of the senior generation and (b) the commitment of the next generation. Results supported an initial level of convergent validity.

Title: Revisiting rules. An ontological study of social rules
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: What kind of things are social rules? I start from the critique of social rules articulated by ethnomethodologists and propose an alternative conception of rules as situated, often tacit, imperatives. This ontological theorization borrows insights from critical realism and post-structuralism to explore general features of rules. For instance: they under-determine fields of legitimate actions, are prone to logical stratification, are anchored to desires and are inherently open to interpretation, though in a discursively structured way. Moreover, I propose that a rule is social if and only if it is internally related to a social relation. In turn, this helps to clarify and systematize an understanding of how social rules relate to social positions and identities. The objectives of this paper are two-fold. Firstly, I initiate a dialogue with authors writing on rules from a realist perspective, in particular John Searle and Tony Lawson. Secondly, I aim to facilitate the development of empirical research on processes of legitimation, authority and power in organizations.

Title: The informational distinctiveness of organizational citizenship behaviors
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Considerable empirical evidence has converged on the finding that organizational citizenship behaviors (OCBs) have a significant impact on managerial performance appraisals and other managerial decisions. However, very little work has been done to investigate why and how managers use citizenship behaviors in their decision making processes. A theoretical explanation of this relationship, termed the informational distinctiveness and accessibility hypothesis, is investigated. It is proposed that OCBs, due to their discretionary nature, are more likely than task behaviors to be attributed to internal causes making them more accessible in memory, leading to increased weighting of OCBs in appraisal decisions. Three laboratory experiments were conducted to test these hypotheses, and results confirm that OCBs appear to be more informationally distinct and accessible than task behaviors. Implications for the performance appraisal and organizational citizenship behavior literatures are discussed.

Title: The internet and regional economic development
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper compares real private investment Expenditure among rural communities in the Province of Alberta, Canada that received a government provided broadband Internet service in December 2000 called "the SuperNet". A transitional period is empirically examined by comparing investment levels 2 years pre-SuperNet and 3 years post-SuperNet. The data indicate an increase in real private investment expenditure among larger SuperNet communities. This indicates the Internet spurs entrepreneurial activities by enabling agglomeration across areas with a pre-existing (pre-SuperNet) cluster of entrepreneurial activities. However, there was a decrease in investment among smaller SuperNet communities with fewer than 10,000 residents. As well, among more geographically remote communities (more than 150 kilometers from a major city), there was a decrease in investment among SuperNet communities with less than 30,000 residents. This indicates that for small rural communities, the Internet enables consumption of items and services not produced within the local community (and typically produced at a lower cost than that which is possible in the local community), and discourages entrepreneurial activities among communities that lack a pre-existing (pre-SuperNet) entrepreneurial cluster. Overall, the data are consistent with the view that virtual entrepreneurial clusters are not independent of real entrepreneurial clusters.

Title: Transformative learning and appreciative inquiry: A more perfect union for deep organizational change
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper identifies how deep change in organizations, catalyzed by Appreciative Inquiry, can be the consequence of simultaneous, synergistic Transformative Learning experienced at the individual level and enacted at the group level. It examines the theoretical and structural framework of these two constructivist views of development. Existing literature within the two perspectives is explored to identify inherent strengths and gaps. A new bridging construct, Transformative Appreciative Inquiry, is proposed which enlightens the potential for sustainable, ongoing adaptation based on the tenets of action technology and inspired by inter- and intra-personal narrative and reflection from a generative perspective.

Title: Scientists or entrepreneurs: Rent (MIS)appropriation from discoveries made in university labs
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Traditional agency theory makes few distinctions between types of agents and instead assumes that opportunistic behavior is largely a function of variability in information asymmetry, with heightened information asymmetry responsible for greater agents' opportunism. This paper redirects attention to an opposite condition in which a unique class of agents-knowledge agents-enjoys heightened levels of autonomy and displays opportunistic conduct albeit under information symmetry. Using a random sample of 54 U.S. research universities and 23,394 scientists, we show how some scientists violate their employment contract when they privately appropriation rent from discoveries they made while working for their institutions. That is, some scientists opt not to license their discoveries through their technology licensing offices (TLOs) and instead privately take their discoveries directly to the market- misappropriate. We find that misappropriation increases with more valuable discoveries and heightened entrepreneurial activities on university campuses. Highly autonomous TLOs and royalty sharing with departments are associated with reduced misappropriation. Taken together, our study-and a stylized mathematical model-suggest that agency theory should better account for conditions in which principals have the information and authority to sanction their agents but instead chose to absorb substantial costs stemming from agents' opportunistic behavior.

Title: How do capabilities emerge and why do some firms develop them while others do not?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: While much research suggests that capabilities are critical for firm performance, surprisingly little is known about how capabilities emerge. Using an inductive research logic and in-depth nested case studies, we explore how executives develop a capability. Specifically, we study how executives develop an internationalization capability. The setting is ten entrepreneurial firms with headquarters in three culturally distinct countries (i.e., Finland, United States, Singapore). Results show that capabilities begin as leaders seed experience with a sense of urgency. Urgency, in turn, fosters a self-reinforcing pattern of connected experiences over time since it biases managerial preferences towards lower risk options. Firms that did not develop capabilities had no urgency to start and had random, unconnected experiences. Capabilities further unfold through mere exposure. Frequent formal and informal communication among headquarters and country operations facilitates positive affect leading to greater pro-social behavior and increased incentives for the sharing of best practices. In contrast, infrequent communication leads to negative affect, lack of trust, and an increased probability of knowledge suppression. Finally, capabilities develop from organizational resilience, where paradoxically change is fueled by stability. Overall, we attempt to provide a more relevant and accurate view of how capabilities come to exist. Instead of promoting a conception of capabilities as a simple function of luck or more experience this study sheds light on the specific types and combinations of mechanisms firms use to generate capabilities. In doing so, this study helps to open the "black box" of capability creation and thus helps fill a significant gap in the literature.
Index Keywords: Capability; Entrepreneurial firms; Firm Performance; Informal communication; Internationalization; Positive affects; Self reinforcing; Strategic process

Title: Reproducing knowledge: Inaccurate replication and failure in franchise organizations
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The recognition that better use of existing knowledge can enhance performance has spawned substantial interest in the replication of productive knowledge within organizations. In particular, it has been argued that, when guided by a template, the exploitation of a business model by replication is more successful if the template is copied precisely. We report the first large sample empirical investigation of this proposition by examining the effect that deviation from prescribed practice has on the survival chances of franchise units within a large non-food franchise organization. We present extensive empirical evidence based on a unique longitudinal dataset tracking all U.S. units of that franchise system from 1991 to 2001. Our analyses provide strong support for the merit of precise replication: units that deviate from the product mix recommended by their franchisor or offer non-standard products are significantly more likely to cease operations.

Title: Stakeholder theory and competitive advantage
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Despite its influence on early development of the field, stakeholder theory is not widely used by strategic management scholars to explain competitive advantage. Using some of the central ideas of resource-based theory, we provide a fresh perspective on why firms that attend to the needs of a broad group of stakeholders may enjoy competitive advantages that are not available to other firms. The key is that these firms have a better understanding of their primary stakeholders' utility functions, which provides them with an enhanced ability to recognize value-creating opportunities. Value appropriation issues are also addressed.

Title: Paternalistic leadership: A review and agenda for future research
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The growing interest in paternalistic leadership research has led to a recent proliferation of diverse definitions and perspectives, as well as a limited number of empirical studies. Consequently, the diversity of perspectives have resulted in conceptual ambiguities, as well as contradictory empirical findings. In this paper, we review research on paternalistic leadership in an effort to assess the current state of the literature. We investigate the construct of paternalistic leadership, review the findings related to its outcomes and antecedents as well as the various measurement scales used in paternalistic leadership research. Based on this review, the article concludes with an agenda for future theoretical and empirical research on this emerging and intriguing new area for leadership research.

Title: Culturally intelligent negotiators: The impact of CQ on intercultural negotiation effectiveness
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Although scholars have repeatedly touted the practical importance of being able to negotiate effectively across cultures, paradoxically, no study has directly addressed what predicts intercultural negotiation effectiveness. In this study, we examined the role of cultural intelligence (CQ) as a potential predictor of intercultural negotiation effectiveness. The negotiation transcripts of 124 American and East Asian negotiators (62 dyads) were coded for joint sequencing of integrative behaviors as well as sequencing of cooperative relationship management behaviors. CQ measured a week prior to negotiations, and aggregated to the dyad level, predicted the extent to which negotiators sequenced integrative behaviors, which in turn predicted joint profit. CQ predicted integrative sequences over and beyond international experience, openness to experience, extraversion, empathy, cognitive ability and emotional intelligence. Exploratory analyses revealed that this effect was largely driven by the motivational facet of CQ. Furthermore, the minimum CQ score within the dyad was enough to predict integrative sequences, showing that the extent to which negotiation processes can be improved is limited to the lowest ability negotiator.

Title: Complementary effects of value and satisfaction on customer's behavioral intentions
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: As companies shift their operations to the Internet, managers have been forced to adapt their operations to embrace the unique dynamics of consumer exchanges online. In doing so, net enabled organizations (NEOs) face the daunting task of not only satisfying the customer through service and technological excellence, but also delivering a value propo-sition that inspires customer loyalty in a highly competitive environment. Traditionally, these NEOs have relied on models of decision making based in IT or offline services in isolation, but these approaches may not provide the insight required to truly predict consumers' intentions toward a specific firm. This research integrates IT and services re-search to develop and test a comprehensive model of consumer decision making online. The model is tested using data collected from a panel of customers from four online home delivery grocers across two years. The data is analyzed using the panel data method that provides a more robust test of the model as it corrects for problems associ-ated with omitted variables. Results provide strong support for the role of both IT-based and service variables in consumer decision making online. Moreover, interaction results suggest that value and satisfaction have synergistic, multiplicative effects on intentions to reuse the service.

Title: Structure, process, and psychosocial characteristics in executive management teams: The case of the multi-business group
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This inductive case study examines an unexplored unit of executive leadership in large complex organizations, the multi-business group. The multi-business group is comprised of each individual general manager of the firm's business-units. Because these general managers exercise significant control and authority of their business-unit resources, their individual and collective actions can have significant firm consequences - positive or negative. Accordingly, business-unit general managers can be a unit of internal firm governance and source of strategic action. Yet, despite the significance of this particular executive management group, we know little about them. Moreover, we have little direct understanding of the structures, processes, or psychosocial characteristics of the multi-business group specifically or executive management teams, like top-management-teams, generally - as indicated by the continual calls for more in-depth observational studies of top-management-teams. This study begins to address these gaps in the literature. The result is theory that describes the association between characteristics of the multi-business group and its association with significant firm outcomes. When the multi-business group operates as a team, higher firm performance is the result and when they do not, the result is lower firm performance. This study thus contributes theory related to executive management teams, such as top-management teams and multi-business groups, and introduces a detailed description of the multibusiness group to the literature.

Title: Knowledge resources for university spinoffs: The role of the academic entrepreneur
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: University spin-offs are seen as having unique resource endowments because of their institutional origins. These resource endowments may be enhanced through the founder. We explore the role of the founding entrepreneur in biotechnology spin-offs. Using multi-level case studies of three human therapeutics companies, we track the development of resources and linkages between the host university and the spin-off. Our results suggest that founders play a critical role in marshalling both finances and knowledge, using local and international linkages, and that they are the primary channel for securing and embedding new knowledge in the firm.

Title: National institutions and managerial discretion: A taxonomy of 24 countries
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Managerial discretion concerns the degree to which senior executives are able to shape a firm's strategic actions and eventual performance outcomes. I argue that discretion will differ systematically across countries in line with variance in four fundamental national institutions - legal tradition, prevailing firm ownership structure, labor market flexibility, and cultural values. I construct a taxonomy of 24 high-income (developed) countries on the basis of these institutions. Several multi-country groups emerge from this taxonomy.

Title: Change recipients' beliefs and justice: The moderating role of leader-member exchange
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Organizational change beliefs have been strongly linked to perceptions of organizational justice in existing research. In addition, employee justice perceptions have been positively related to LMX in previous studies. A new organizational change beliefs scale, which place importance on both the change message and the change messenger, is examined in terms of justice perceptions relating to both change message and messenger components. Hypotheses are offered regarding how each dimension of the change belief scale relates to one or more types of justice perceptions, and how LMX moderates some of those relationships. The paper includes both practical and theoretical implications for this research.

Title: Learning and small firm growth: The role of entrepreneurial orientation
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Organization learning has been proposed as necessary for firms to successfully adapt to changing environmental conditions. Hence, firms with an orientation or cultural values toward learning might be expected to more successfully adapt in the face of environmental dynamism and a more successful adaptation should translate to better performance. This study examines the relationship between an orientation toward learning and small business growth and the potential role that an entrepreneurial orientation may have in the relationship. We argue that organizational values (learning orientation) work through actions (entrepreneurial orientation) to affect firm outcomes (growth performance). Data from a cross section of 105 small manufacturing firms is analyzed to test hypothesized relationships. We find strong support for the contention that entrepreneurial orientation plays a mediating role in the influence of an orientation to learn and the growth performance of small firms. The implications of our findings and directions for future research are also discussed.

Title: The importance of intangible social attributes in individual purchasing decisions: A multi-country comparative study
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper examines the role that intangible attributes-brand, country of origin and environmental and labor conditions-play in product choice across six countries. Our results show that: 1) brand is more important for consumers in developing countries purchasing high involvement products, 2) social attributes are generally more influential in developed countries, and 3) some country consumers exhibited very strong domestic country biases when making decisions about purchases. We believe that our results offer a more accurate picture of the role of intangibles since they are based on multi-cue, multi-product design that forced consumers to make tradeoffs between tangible and intangible attributes.

Title: What about us? Relative deprivation among out-group members in leader-member exchange relationships
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Leader-member exchange (LMX) theory posits that leaders develop special relationships with certain employees. By and large, prior studies have emphasized the positive aspects of LMX relationships for employees who have high-quality exchange relationships with their supervisors (i.e., in-group employees). Indeed, research indicates that employees who are part of the in-group tend to be given more interesting tasks to work on, have more positive job attitudes, achieve greater career success, and so on. The plight of out-group members, though, has received far less attention from researchers. In particular, given the benefits that tend to accrue to in-group employees, workers who have low-quality exchange relationships with their supervisors are likely to be disappointed with their out-group status. Using relative deprivation theory, then, this research examines the situations in which out-group members are most likely to feel aggrieved. Relative deprivation theory is also used to understand the ways in which employees may respond to feelings of relative deprivation associated with out-group status and how relative deprivation may affect individual outcomes and group performance. Some implications of this research and directions for future research are discussed as well.

Title: Institutionalizing change in organizations: Structures, routines and symbols
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: How do new ideas and practices get institutionalized within firms? In the transition between old and new institutionalism, emphasis has progressively shifted from the analysis of single large organizations to organizational fields. So, while we know more about the phenomena of inter-organizational legitimation, there is still much to learn about intra-organizational processes of institutional change, how new ideas and practices interact with existent structures, routines and symbols. In this paper I enrich the perspective on intra-organizational change posed by institutional theory, discussing how the insights gained from analysis of related topics in the literature can favor a more robust understanding of the substantive and symbolic elements of evolution in organizations, as well as providing a more comprehensive model of intra-organizational dynamics. The result is an extended model of the intra-organizational institutional processes of change, expanding Tolbert and Zucker (1996) with the additional dimensions brought by the literature on configuration, organizational identity, agency and routines. This model adds to the current theoretical understanding as it explicitly account for the interplay between material and symbolic organizational elements, building a perspective that can enrich the analysis of the unfolding of change within organizations.

Title: The role of industry context and managerial discretion in strategic renewal through R & D programs and CVC deals
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Internal research and development is commonly used to develop new competencies and skills. More recently, corporate venture capital has become an increasingly prominent mechanism that enables organizations to reinvent themselves. We examine the strategic renewal efforts of entire industries via their use of both internal research and development and corporate venture capital deals. We argue that industry conditions such as technological change and industry standards create both pressure and opportunity for renewal. However, managers ultimately pursue such renewal opportunities, and the discretion of managers varies across industries. We suggest that industries where managers have greater latitude for action are better able to respond to the pressures and opportunities for pursuing strategic renewal through both internal and external venturing. We find that the combination of managerial discretion and industry environment in combination motivates the strategic renewal efforts of industries. Our results are largely consistent across internal research and development and the use of corporate venture capital.

Title: Knowledge transfer and enjoyment in classroom versus on-line settings: A test of "stickiness factors
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Drawing on motivation theory and Szulanski's model of "stickiness factors" for knowledge transfer, we develop and test a model of student enjoyment and learning performance in classroom versus on-line education. We find that trust in the instructor's expertise, content relevance, and the classroom context enhance student enjoyment. Enjoyment is positively associated with learning performance in the classroom, but not on-line, and student ability is positively associated with learning performance in the online context, but not in the classroom.

Title: Doing well by doing good: Pursuing commercial success by internalizing social good in subsistence markets
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper examines the strategies that successful firms employ in subsistence markets. Using qualitative research and case studies, we argue that it is essential for firms to internalize social good in order to succeed in subsistence markets. In other words, customer and societal welfare concerns move from the periphery to the center of strategic planning and to permeate business functions and processes. We do not propose that the business exists for the social good; but rather that business exists for making profits and that in the subsistence context, the pursuit of social good will increase the likelihood of commercial success. We develop a set of propositions about selected aspects of business processes such as product development and pricing.

Title: How intra-firm and inter-firm expertise affect the sourcing decisions of technologically interdependent components
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Theories of the firm generally posit that firms determine their boundaries through sourcing choices of individual components. However, this framework neglects the possibility for technological interdependence between components that can affect these choices and lead firms to make joint decisions for multiple components. Using resource-based theories, we explore this overlooked area by investigating how firms source technologically interdependent components and test our predictions by exploiting a rich dataset that includes sourcing choices several components, including pairs that are interdependent and those that are unrelated. We expand the range of choices from a make/buy dichotomy to a trichotomy that includes concurrent sourcing, which arises when firm simultaneously make and buy a given component. We find that firms tend to source technologically interdependent components via the same mode and that firm, intrafirm, and interfirm expertise tend to influence the choice of mode. Most strikingly, firms concurrently source technologically interdependent components when there is the opportunity to leverage the combined expertise of the firm and its suppliers. By contrast, expertise has little influence on common sourcing decisions of technologically unrelated components.

Title: Network structures, individual behavior and performance in organizations
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Relational approaches to organization typically ignore processes of network formation while studying network consequences, and, symmetrically, ignore the implications of network structures and flows while studying network antecedents. In this paper we address these symmetric weaknesses in the organizational literature on networks consequences and antecedents by specifying dynamic models for the joint representation of network selection and influence processes. We estimate our models using a set of longitudinal data that we have collected on a sample of graduate students enrolled in a professional management degree. We report clear evidence of influence on individual performance of a variety of network motifs defined over interpersonal relations of advice seeking and contribution to individual learning. Controlling for a variety of different sources of homophily (like, for example, age and gender) and for a number of endogenous local network effects (like, for example, transitivity and reciprocity) we find that performance of individual subjects tends to be assimilated to the performance of others who contribute to their learning and from whom they seek advice. We also find evidence in support of our contention that models accounting for the co-evolution of network structures and individual behavior are statistically more informative than models that specify these two processes separately. Finally we document how individual performance is both the outcome of local network-based processes as well as a basis for social selection in the advice network, but not in the contribution to learning network.

Title: MBA market differentiation: An analysis of recruiter perceptions and school characteristics
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study analyzed MBA starting salaries as a function of corporate recruiter perceptions and school characteristics. Data were provided by the Graduate Management Admissions Council (GMAC) as part of a research grant from the GMAC Management Education Research Institute. Using data from GMAC's annual Corporate Recruiter Surveys (CRS) from 2002, 2003, and 2004, the perceptions of 2,789 corporate recruiters were analyzed. Additional data on school characteristics were collected to supplement the data on recruiter perceptions. Published business school rankings were found to be the most significant predictor of MBA starting salaries in all three years of the study. Other factors, such as recruiter perceptions of MBA graduates' academic and work experiences, and school characteristics, were also significant. Implications for MBA schools attempting to develop successful differentiation strategies are discussed.

Title: Do firms do 'Worse' by doing 'Bad'? Financial misrepresentation and subsequent firm performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper explores the relationship between business ethics and firm performance. The analysis finds strong support that firms 'do worse by doing bad'; that is, financial misrepresentation leads to decreased legitimacy and impaired performance, and this detrimental impact is observable in the ongoing diminished operational profitability of the firm. Firms that decouple themselves from the misconduct - by increasing board independence or replacing the CEO - ameliorate this negative performance impact.

Title: Understanding the ethical cost of organizational goal-setting: A review and theory development
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Goal-setting has become a popular and effective motivational tool, utilized by practitioners and substantiated with decades of empirical research. However, the potential for goal-setting to enhance performance may come at the cost of ethical behavior. I propose a theoretical model linking attributes of goals and goal-setting practices to unethical behavior through two psychological mechanisms - ethical recognition and moral disengagement; and addressing the moderating role of individual differences (e.g., goal commitment and conscientiousness), as well as the broader organizational ethical context.

Title: Where perception meets reality: The effects of different types of faultline perceptions, asymmetries, and realities on intersubgroup conflict and workgroup outcomes
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In this paper, we propose a more nuanced view of the faultline concept, focusing on how the interaction of perceived faultline characteristics and objective faultline characteristics can influence intersubgroup conflict and group outcomes. Using both qualitative and quantitative data, we find that perceived faultlines are positively related to intersubgroup conflict (which fully mediates the effects on emergent states and partially mediates the effects on effective group processes), and that these effects are exacerbated in the presence of objective demographic faultlines, symmetric faultline perceptions, and faultlines perceived to exist based on person-related rather than job-related characteristics.
Index Keywords: Conflict; Diversity; Faultlines; Group process; Quantitative data; Workgroups

Title: Empirical relationships between theories of servant, transformational, and transactional leadership
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study endeavored to provide empirical support for servant leadership theory by investigating its relationships with more empirically supported theories of transformational leadership and transactional leadership (i.e., contingent reward, active/passive management-by-exception, laissez faire). Using questionnaire data from 207 employees of five organizations, this study found employees' perceptions of their supervisors' servant leadership to be positively related not only to employees' perceptions of their supervisors' transformational leadership but also their supervisors' contingent reward leadership and active management-by-exception leadership. Perceived servant leadership was negatively related to perceived passive management-by-exception leadership and laissez faire leadership. Implications and areas for future research are discussed.

Title: Managing multiple change processes: Challenges and intervention techniques
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper presents an alternative perspective on change management. We argue that while many organizations today pursue multiple and interrelated changes, existing change theories present change as isolated events and processes in the organization. As a consequence, some of our most common intervention models insufficiently reflect the challenges that organizations that pursue multiple changes meet. Based on a study of the Norwegian financial sector, which has gone through dramatic changes in the last fifteen years, we show that the main challenges in organizations that pursue multiple changes are not related to mobilizing for change, but rather attending to daily operations while continuously implementing changes. Compared to traditional prescriptions such as Lewin's unfreeze-move-refreeze or Weick and Quinn's freeze-rebalance- unfreeze, we propose five change management techniques which span beyond isolated and single change perspectives and which contradicts some of the more common prescriptions for change management.

Title: Pro-profit, pro-growth, or both? strategic ambidexterity and performance in international new ventures (INV)
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We draw on the ambidextrous organization literature to propose that international new ventures (INVs) that concurrently pursue 'strategic ambidexterity'-paradoxical strategies of pro-profit and pro-growth- can outperform firms that pursue only one of these strategies. We develop the pro-profit and pro-growth dimensions, propose hypotheses, and test them using data from 82 Canadian INVs. This article is one of the first theoretical and empirical attempts to link strategic ambidexterity and INV performance. Our findings suggest that INVs that embrace pro-profit and pro-growth paradoxical strategies achieve superior performance.

Title: Global prerequisites of politics, pay and pipeline for the presence of women corporate directors
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: A growing body of ethics research investigates gender diversity and governance on corporate boards, at individual and firm levels, in single country studies. In this study, we explore the environmental context of female representation on corporate boards of directors, using data from forty-three countries. We suggest that women's representation on corporate boards may be shaped by the larger environment, including the social, political and economic structures of individual countries. We use logit regression to conduct our analysis. Our results indicate that countries with higher representation of women on boards are more likely to have women in senior management and more equal ratios of male to female pay. However, we find that countries with a longer tradition of women's political representation are less likely to have high levels of female board representation.

Title: Groupthink and the innovator's dilemma: France's sudden and shocking defeat in 1940
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The innovator's dilemma shows how dominant established firms and well-established professional fields often fail to see or address disruptive innovations that are entering their domains and disrupting their activities. These disruptive innovations have been shown to have potentially devastating consequences for organizations and professions that fail to respond to the threats posed. Theorists have proposed that organizations and professions actually do see disruptive innovations and appreciate their threats, but find it difficult to respond because of their dependence on key resource providers, such as major customers or clients. But this may not always be the case: sometimes decision makers may not see the disruption coming at all, or they may completely dismiss the threat. This paper proposes that sometimes groupthink draws decision makers away from seeing and responding to disruptive innovations. It does this by examining one of the greatest military catastrophes in history: France's sudden and utter defeat at the start of World War II. The groupthink phenomenon has potential to augment explanations of disruptive innovation and change by showing how the leadership of an organization or profession may fail to consider alternative technological paths and solutions to problems.

Title: A test of the cross-cultural equivalency of the resistance to change scale in Russia and Ukraine
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We examined the cross-cultural measurement equivalency of Oreg's (2003) resistance to change (RTC) scale, a measure developed and validated in the U.S., in the transitioning economies of Russia and Ukraine. RTC is a direct measure of an individual's disposition toward avoiding or resisting change, which we believe is paramount to understanding organizational change phenomena in transitional contexts, and thereby generating prescriptive guidelines. Structural equation results indicate that three of the four factors proposed by Oreg (2003), routine seeking, emotional reaction, and short-term thinking, provide a psychometrically sound global measure of the RTC construct in Russia and Ukraine. This specification of RTC performs as predicted in a nomological set, and can be used for more fine grained analyses of individual resistors to change in the post-Soviet context.

Title: When task competence is irrelevant: The role of interpersonal affect in instrumental ties
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper examines the role of interpersonal affect in networks of instrumental action in organizations. We aim to answer two related questions. First, does interpersonal affect modify the use of task competence as a criterion for the formation of instrumental ties? Second, does negative affect influence the role of task competence in instrumental relationships differently than positive affect? Based on a methodology drawing from social psychological models of interpersonal perception and hierarchical Bayesian models for social network analysis, we investigated these questions with data from three network studies of an entrepreneurial computer technology company, staff personnel at an academic institution, and employees in a large information technology corporation. Across all the organizational contexts and tasks we analyzed, we found that, in the presence of negative affect, competence was largely irrelevant as a criterion for the formation of instrumental ties. By contrast, under conditions of positive affect, increases in task competence had a consistently positive effect on the likelihood of work interaction. We conclude that, by changing how people seek out and access the competence of their colleagues, the structure of interpersonal affect has pervasive consequences for the functioning of organizations.

Title: How do new ventures evolve? The process of charter change in technology ventures
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper presents a process study of new venture evolution. We introduce the concept of a venture charter - the shared understanding of the elements of business that the venture leaders assume responsibility for - and we show how the charters of four technology-based new ventures shift dramatically over the early stages of their evolution. The evidence suggests that new ventures rarely follow the classic stages model of venture growth. Instead, they conform to a modified version of punctuated equilibrium where the elements of the charter exist in stable misalignment before going through a period of upheaval to another stable, but misaligned, configuration. The research provides insights into new venture evolution, the theory of organizational charters, and punctuated equilibrium perspectives on organizational change.
Index Keywords: Charters; Evolution; New ventures; Organizational change; Punctuated equilibrium; Shared understanding; Technology ventures; Technology-based

Title: Extending the staged model of foreign expansion: Crossborder syndication by UK PE firms in continental Europe, 1990- 2005
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: PE (PE) has become an increasingly international phenomenon both in terms of the sums of money involved and its geographical diversity. The issue of cross-border syndication, however, has been a neglected issue in the PE literature. We extent the staged model of international expansion by examining the role of PE firm experience, experience at the PE industry level, human resource intensity and differences in legal environment as determinants of cross-border syndication. We examine these issues by studying the international expansion by later-stage UK PE investors into Europe over the period 1990 to 2005. Implications for theory are suggested.

Title: Market potential evolution for interacting telecommunication technologies in presence of network effects
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study examines how the market potential for interacting communication technologies evolves along the diffusion processes as a consequence of the network effects. We analyze both the level of fit and the long-term predictive validity of alternative adoption models using penetration data on three interacting communication technologies that arguably preset network effects: fixed phones, mobile phones and Internet, covering a total of 214 countries for the time period 1991-2003. We find that firstly, mobile telephony and Internet are fully complementary; secondly, fixed telephony fosters the diffusion of mobile telephony, which on its turn cannibalizes the diffusion of fixed phones; thirdly, fixed telephony facilitates the diffusion of Internet, but Internet diffusion does not have any significant effect on fixed telephony diffusion. The proposed specifications with network externalities outperform the one with a constant market potential and produce better long-term predictions for the growing technologies.

Title: Combinative effects of innovation types on performance: A longitudinal study of public services
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We examine the combinative effects of three innovation types (service, process and administrative) on organizational performance in a five-year panel of 428 English local governments. Results indicate that (1) overall innovative activity matters for organizational performance, (2) that divergence from the norm results in positive rewards, and (3) that a lack of congruence amongst innovation types has a harmful effect on governmental performance. In short, these results suggest that by doing well at innovation, public organizations will come good.

Title: Bayesian overconfidence
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper presents a reconciliation of the three distinct ways in which the research literature has defined overconfidence: (1) overestimation of one's actual performance, (2) overplacement of one's performance relative to those of others, and (3) overprecision in beliefs about the accuracy of one's knowledge.

Title: Connecting group success to individual achievement: Cross-cultural attributions for group performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Recent research suggests that groups attribute the causes of their success to factors that are "internal" but internal attributions can vary by the extent to which they emphasize (1) the contributions made by each individual member of the group or they (2) emphasize the group as a whole. Despite the fact that different types of attributions lead to different performance outcomes, there is no research to address the conditions under which people might emphasize one type of attribution over the other. In this paper we extend existing research on attributions for group performance by describing the factors that shift the focus from attributions to the group as a whole to a focus on the unique contributions made by each individual in the group. We propose that people will explain the causes of group performance differently depending on where they stand on the cultural dimensions of individualism- collectivism and power distance. Our predictions are tested in a scenario study conducted in both the United States and India in which participants are given equivalent information about the individuals in the group and about the shared properties of the group as a whole. We conclude by discussing the implications of our results for managing teams in different cultures.

Title: Sociopolitical dynamics in relations between top managers and security analysts
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study develops and tests a sociopolitical perspective on relations between corporate managers and security analysts. We draw from theory and research on interpersonal influence and social exchange to suggest how the disclosure of negative firm information such as unexpectedly low corporate earnings may prompt top executives to engage in social influence tactics toward security analysts in the form of personal and professional favor-doing, and we consider how executive favors may prompt analysts to reciprocate by issuing relatively positive ratings of the firm. We also extend our theoretical framework to suggest how a relatively negative analyst rating (i.e., downgrade) may prompt executives to engage in negative reciprocity or retaliation against the analyst, and how such negative reciprocity could deter other analysts from issuing negative ratings of the focal firm. Specifically, we propose that analysts who downgrade a firm's stock may tend to receive less personal access to the firm's top executives, and that analysts who are aware of a colleague's loss of access to executives after downgrading a firm will be less likely subsequently to downgrade that firm. We test our theory with original large-sample survey data on interpersonal relations between managers and analysts combined with archival data on analyst stock recommendations, and the findings are supportive. Given that analyst recommendations have a significant influence on investor behavior, firm reputation and access to capital, our theory and supportive findings ultimately suggest how corporate leaders can enhance and perpetuate external support for their firms by engaging in social influence and exchange processes toward a key external constituent of the firm. We also discuss implications for the literatures on financial market behavior and corporate control.
Author Keywords: Corporate governance; Social influence; Top management
Index Keywords: Managers; Network security; Corporate control; Corporate governance; Corporate managers; Interpersonal influences; Interpersonal relations; Social influence; Theoretical framework; Top management; Economic and social effects

Title: Chameleons bake bigger pies and take bigger pieces: Strategic behavioral mimicry facilitates negotiation outcomes
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Two experiments investigated the hypothesis that strategic behavioral mimicry can facilitate negotiation outcomes. Study 1 used an employment negotiation with multiple issues, and demonstrated that strategic behavioral mimicry facilitated outcomes at both the individual and dyadic levels: Negotiators who mimicked the mannerisms of their opponents secured better individual outcomes, but dyads as a whole also performed better when mimicking occurred compared to when it did not. Thus, mimickers created more value and then claimed most of that additional value for themselves, though not at the expense of their opponents. In Study 2, mimicry facilitated negotiators!) Eability to uncover underlying compatible interests and increased the likelihood of obtaining a deal in a negotiation where a prima facie solution was not possible. Results from Study 2 also demonstrated that interpersonal trust mediated the relationship between mimicry and deal-making. Implications for our understanding of negotiation dynamics and interpersonal coordination are discussed.

Title: Exploring temporal patterns in firms' scale and scope activities and their performance implications
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The claim that organizations competing in highly turbulent environments behave chaotically has been prominent in contingency, co-alignment and co-evolution research. The term chaotic, however, has mostly been used in a vernacular manner. Whether organizations indeed behave chaotic in their scale and scope activities in the scientific sense of the term - though unpredictable, but still deterministic - has remained unexplored so far. Based on a longitudinal analysis of the scale and scope activities of eight German multi-business firms within turbulent and non-turbulent industries, the paper thus explores whether firms competing in turbulent environments show truly chaotic or random patterns in their scale and scope activities and whether firms in non-turbulent environments display predictable stable or periodic patterns in their scale and scope activities. Moreover, the study investigates whether firms which adjust the temporal pattern of their scale and scope activities to the degree of turbulence and dynamic of their industry in fact outperform those firms which fail to do so. Results show that not only firms in turbulent but also firms in non-turbulent environments display random patterns in their scale and scope activities. Counterintuitively, we even find that firms with random patterns in non-turbulent industries outperform those with stable/periodic patterns. In turbulent industries, firms with chaotic patterns show higher accounting performance than firms with random patterns.

Title: Relationship of safety climate and safety performance in hospitals
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Objective. To examine the association betweefi measures of hospital safety culture and hospital performance on selected indicators of patient safety. Data Sources. Primary data from a 38-item, 2004- 2005 survey of hospital personnel, and secondary data from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality's Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project State Inpatient Databases from 2000, the 2002 American Hospital Association's Annual Survey of Hospitals. Study Design. Cross-sectional study of 47 hospitals to assess the relationship between safety culture and 14 hospital-level patient safety indicators (PSIs). Data Collection. Regressions with PSIs as dependent variables and hospital safety climate scores and controls as independent variables. Some specifications included individual, work unit, and organizational safety climate dimensions. Others included separate measures for senior managers and front line personnel's and for physicians and nurses' perceptions of safety culture. Principal Findings. Dimensions of safety climate that measured individual beliefs exhibited significant, positive relationships with PSIs. However, work unit and organizational dimensions, and a composite measure of safety climate across all dimensions, did not. Perceptions of front line personnel, but not senior managers, exhibited a relationship with PSIs. Where nurses reported less fear of blame, hospitals had lower rates of PSIs overall and of nurse-sensitive PSIs. Conclusions. Results link dimensions of hospital safety climate to indicators of patient safety. They suggest that measures of safety climate based on perceptions of front-line personnel are more strongly correlated with PSIs than measures based on senior-managers' perceptions. Perceptions of safety culture among nurses and doctors differ in their relationships to indicators.

Title: Public-private networks and upgrading capabilities: A parametric stroll through argentine vineyards
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper uses a unique research design to statistically analyze the impact of inter-firm networks and publicly supported institutions on firm upgrading capabilities. Our examination of the transformation of the Argentine wine industry in two provinces reveals the importance of a firm's "public-private" network. Links to other firms and institutions appear especially helpful to the extent they help the firm gain access to different communities of producers. Governments can aid upgrading and competitiveness, especially in backward societies, by building public-private institutions that not only offer supply-side resources to firms but also act as bridges across regions.

Title: The over-educated, under-utilized worker: Why doesn't human capital development bring desired outcomes?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This comparative study of human capital development and organizational practices examines public administrators' perceptions of organizational human capital utilization (and underutilization), its causes and effects. It develops and tests an integrated model of utilization and its correlates in public sector organizations. The analysis is based on a recent survey of public administrators (n=540) in two countries-Oman and Saudi Arabia. The study findings expose a significant, and largely ignored, problem in the development and management of public sector organizations: "human capital resource underutilization", indicating that skills and abilities of public administrators, although relatively and increasingly abundant, are invariably underutilized. The results show that competence utilization is closely related to certain organizational practices, namely power-influence sharing in decision making, area of expertise-job content matching, qualification-job requirements matching, and the use of work-teams. Effective utilization results in increasing job satisfaction, worker's retention, and effectiveness and quality of decisions. To date little research has successfully addressed these theoretical arguments especially in public sector organizations. The study has profound implications for organizational development and reform. Without effective mechanisms to activate and utilize human capital resources, additional skill development might prove ineffective and largely irrelevant to performance improvements and overall effectiveness of governance system.

Title: Work engagement: A meta-analytic review and directions for research in an emerging area
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Work engagement is a construct that has recently emerged as part of the trend toward positive psychology. This study reviews the engagement construct using a meta-analytic framework. First, we review the engagement construct and empirical research. Second, we present a meta-analysis of the correlates of the most commonly used measure of engagement, the Utrecht Work Engagement Scale (UWES; Schaufeli, Salanova, Gonzalez-Roma, & Bakker, 2002). Meta-analytic results show that the three factors of engagement (i.e. vigor, dedication, and absorption) are strongly inter-correlated. Also, we found that engagement is more strongly related to job resources than job demands. Finally, we found that the dimensions of engagement predict organizational commitment and individual health outcomes in a manner consistent with predictions. We conclude with a discussion of the future directions that we believe engagement research should take.

Title: Multilevel integration of exploration units : Beyond the ambidextrous organization
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper addresses the integration mechanisms settled in large multidivisional organizations in order to combine incremental and radical innovations. Recent work emphasizes that in order to maintain its competitive advantage, a firm should be able to balance exploration and exploitation. But few works analyze how firms do it. We developed an in-depth case study. The company we studied, a large multidivisional automotive supplier, wanted to enhance its growth through innovation and so created a unit dedicated to the development of radical innovations. Taking an ethnographic approach we outlined the tensions that developed between this exploratory entity and the other divisions and focused on the integration mechanisms through which the firm outcomes these tensions. We suggest that integration takes place on a multilevel basis: the top management that appoint and support the leader of the exploratory unit, the leader that develop formal and informal interactions with the divisions' senior executives, the divisions' VPs and senior executives and the middle level managers that are in the divisions and that participate in the projects of the exploration entity. Our analysis shows four types of integration mechanisms: permanent cross-divisional working groups, ad hoc cross-divisional committee meetings, assigning transversal subjects to a high status actor and the initiatives of key individuals working both for the entity and a division.
