Title: Capabilities and technological change: Science vs business based entrepreneurs and new venture performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Drawing on the idea that capabilities are context specific to the competitive environment; this paper argues that entrepreneurial scientists and business entrepreneurs will react differently to venturing opportunities afforded by technological change. It also suggests that the value of capabilities of venture founders, and new ventures performance, will differ based on the technological change faced at venture entry. We show that talented entrepreneurial scientists are more likely to enter prior to a dramatic technological shift, and talented business entrepreneurs are less likely to enter. Ventures founded after a technological shift are worth more, but have lower success rates. We find opposing results of capabilities on venture value and performance. Scientific and business capabilities add market value before the discontinuity, but enhance performance after. The findings provide support for linking the origin of capabilities with the competitive environment, and of capabilities as an inflow in addition to a determinant of outcomes.

Title: National governance systems, stakeholder power, and post-acquisition dynamics
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We argue that post-acquisition dynamics are driven by the power of organizational stakeholders. Downsizing of the target company, resource transfers from the acquirer, and enhanced performance of the target are more likely to occur when the new owners can exert more power than the old owners, and when the target's employees are less powerful. We also expect more experienced acquirers to be able to overcome the likely resistance of powerful employees more easily. Using survey responses from 190 North American and European acquirers of as many as 253 targets located in 27 different countries, we find support for the effects of stakeholder rights and experience on some post-acquisition dynamics and outcomes. We highlight the crucial role that power plays in the pursuit of value creation in the wake of corporate acquisitions noting that both owners and employees have at their disposal tools to advance their interests.

Title: Contracting, incentives and inter-organizational routines in Information Technology outsourcing
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Firms often use formal or explicit contracts as governance devices to administer, manage and coordinate market-based transactions such as outsourced information technology (IT) initiatives. While research in economics highlights the need to design contracts effectively to minimize hazards of opportunism and provide mutual incentives for the parties to fulfill their obligations, the role of knowledge exchange and protection in these client-vendor agreements and their implications for incentive alignment are not clear. In this paper, we analyze a sample of IT outsourcing contracts to investigate contract design, specifically the mechanisms adopted by firms to protect key knowledge assets that might be crucial to a firm's capabilities. We further examine how the incentive sharing mechanisms adopted by the client-vendor dyad reflects the knowledge asymmetries and knowledge exchange mechanisms that exist in the clientvendor relationship. Our findings help us test explanations from agency theory and arguments from prior knowledge-based research.

Title: Promoting the penguin: Who is advocating open source software in commercial settings?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Today, all firms using or developing software are facing the question if and how to engage in open source software (OSS). Yet, little is known about the process of OSS adoption and diffusion within corporations. We address this issue. In light of qualitative evidence on the role of programmers in promoting OSS, we focus on the attitudes of employed IT professionals towards corporate OSS engagement. Our analysis is based on 25 interviews and a large-scale survey with 404 participants, performed at the telecommunications department of a multinational company and guided by the theoretical frameworks of Rogers (innovation diffusion) and Davis (Technology Acceptance Model). Our main findings concern the impact of the respondent's job function. They are consistent with theoretical considerations - and still rather surprising. Distinguishing between developers, testers, architects, project managers, and managers, we find that software testers are generally most favorable towards heightening OSS activities, followed by software architects and managers. Apart from project managers, developers are actually least favorable towards increased corporate OSS engagement, despite their large experience in working on OSS. Since developers constitute both the basic level of software development and the largest of the named groups, this finding leads us to question that OSS is a generally supported grassroots movement. Introducing OSS and open innovation processes to a corporation thus requires taking each individual's incentives based on her job function into account, and a close look at organizational aspects.

Title: Does money cost too much? The effect of going public on innovation in high-technology firms
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: A critical component of corporate research and development (R&D) efforts is access to funding. To raise the large amounts of capital required for continued growtfi, R&D-intensive start-ups must often turn to initial public offerings (IPOs). Yet, these transactions are not simply short-term events that infuse capital into firms, but instead delineate distinct stages in the evolution of high-tech ventures, and may subsequently shape the very innovative activities they are funding. Recent work has characterized IPOs as "transformational" events likely to trigger significant changes in core organizational features. Few empirical papers, however, have examined the effects of going public on firms' long-term operating processes. This study investigates whether and how going public affects firms' innovative activities. I propose that an IPO fundamentally reshapes a firm's internal operations, and consider implications for the firm's overall rate of innovation and its innovation search strategies. Using longitudinal data on 770 venture capital-backed U.S. medical device firms receiving their first rounds of funding between 1980 and 2005,1 find that a firm's overall rate of innovation increases after the firm goes public. Going public also increases the proportion of innovative search that exploits internally developed knowledge and the rate of exploratory innovation building on public-sector knowledge. I use inverse probability of treatment and censoring weights to account for self-selection into IPO and the presence of time-dependent confounders; estimates represent population average treatment effects.

Title: The concept of sustainable entrepreneurship: A conceptual framework and empirical analysis
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We provide a holistic approach to the entrepreneurial phenomenon by introducing the concept of 1 "sustainable entrepreneurship" (SE). Based on the literature of sustainable development, we define St as the teleological process that creates value in three distinctive dimensions: the social, economic and environmental, which are presented, analyzed and synthesized in a unifying framework. Since the field of contemporary business success lies on these three levels, we argue that SE provides a holistic approach for organizational strategic development. A case study is presented as an example of how SE can be materialized and offer opportunities for doing well by doing good.

Title: Temporality of the mobilisation process encountered by the institutional entrepreneur
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In institutional theories, interaction patterns studied are essentially already set and few studies really succeed in capturing the complexity of the activities that the institutional entrepreneur must manage in order to stabilise relationships and align actors. This article aims to fill in this missing gap by unveiling the micro-processes of the mobilisation process carried out by an institutional entrepreneur. If the question of how a new institution is created - which entails legitimacy building, and allies' mobilisation and discourse usage to carry the message - has been raised using a large array of perspectives, what has not yet been dealt with is the temporality of the process. Based on an in depth case study of an institution in the making, we consider, as Amis et al. (2004), the temporality, the pace and the sequence of the mobilisation process carried out with the aim to create a new institution. We study a multi-level case which involves actors at different geographical, organisational and cognitive levels. Only Aldrich and Fiol (1994) strive to explore the temporality of a new industry until its institutionalisation is taken as anchorage to legitimacy-building issues. The entrepreneur needs to cross different worlds/levels; in each, a specific component of legitimacy is built and allows passage to the next level. In contrast, our findings suggest that the mobilisation process is neither linear nor sequential: it is made up of iterations and reaches different levels simultaneously. At least this is what a statistical analysis combining themes of the presentations and affiliation of the audience leads us to conclude. The first conclusion is that the institutional entrepreneur's work entails enrolling heterogeneous actors in three different spheres. These are different, but complementary to Aldrich and Fiol's one (1994): we also try to go beyond a simple internal/external presentation of the mobilisation process and found three levels: a global network (strategic), a local network (operational) and the larger environment. This is to say that audiences can not be characterised in advance. The institutional entrepreneur navigates between the three spheres and constitutes the essential link between the three. An important conclusion to draw from this categorization is the fact that in the early phase of the mobilisation process, the new institution is promoted essentially from and for the outside world.
Index Keywords: Cognitive levels; Institutional entrepreneur; Institutional theory; Institutionalisation; Interaction pattern; Mobilisation; Specific component; Temporality

Title: Opportunity recognition and exploitation by necessity and opportunity entrepreneurs: Empirical evidence from earnings equations
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Our paper uses data from the German Socio Economic Panel Study (GSOEP) to analyze how necessity and opportunity entrepreneurs differ in kind and their ability to recognize and ex-ploit entrepreneurial opportunities, measured as earnings in self-employment. We estimate a probit model as well as random effects panel data models in order to address these questions. We find that the two types of entrepreneurs differ as concerns age, gender and other charac-teristics, but not with regard to education level. Opportunity entrepreneurs pursue more prof-itable entrepreneurial opportunities, and the determinants of the profitability on the entrepreneurial opportunity pursued differ to some degree. We conclude that our findings indicate a need to distinguish between the two groups in entrepreneurship theory as well as policy-making. The results also show that commonly used specifications of earnings equations seem to work better for opportunity than for necessity entrepreneurs.

Title: Legal system and rule of law effects on us cross-listing to bond by emerging-market firms
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: An emerging "bonding hypothesis" holds that a firm's geographic domicile may not determine its corporate governance destiny. Firms from countries with weaker corporate governance regimes can internationalize their legal (but not necessarily operational) presence by cross-listing their securities on overseas financial markets. They can "bond" with legal systems and enforcement policies in foreign corporate governance regimes providing stronger investor protection. Cross-listing to bond increases firm value by decreasing corporate misconduct, broadening the investor base, and lowering the cost of capital. We document evidence of cross-listing to bond with stronger legal systems and rule of law by more than 700 firms from 23 emerging-market countries cross-listing their securities on US financial markets from 1996-2002. We find that: 1) US cross-listing levels are lower for firms from Common Law countries providing stronger investor protection, but only in Common Law countries with weaker rule of law; and 2) US cross-listing levels are higher for firms from Civil Law countries providing weaker investor protection, but only in Civil Law countries with stronger rule of law. Emerging-market firms exhibit behavior consistent with bonding hypothesis considerations and cross-list as a commitment to a more rigorous corporate governance regime, but the behavior is contingent and depends on examination of both legal system and rule of law effects individually and in interaction. Our empirical results highlight the importance of broadening investigating of firm internationalization to consider legal dimensions. Firms have discretion to choose foreign corporate governance regimes with less or no regard to where their operations are located.

Title: How much do country differences matter in the performance of organizational routines transferred across borders?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Previous research has indicated that differences between countries have a significant effect on foreign subsidiary performance. Moreover, previous research has suggested that, especially for Multinational corporations, the transfer of knowledge embedded in organizational routines is a primary driver of both firm and subsidiary success. What is not known, however, is the degree to which country differences affect the performance of transferred knowledge. In that regard, this paper addresses two primary questions: 1) to what extent do differences between countries affect the performance of knowledge assets embedded in organizational routines which have been transferred across borders, and 2) which specific differences matter, including their relative weight. We address these questions using a unique longitudinal dataset comprising monthly indicators for a census of all foreign units of a large multinational franchise organization from the inception of its first international unit through 2004.

Title: Collaborative technology support for integrating and applying knowledge in virtual contexts
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Individuals increasingly engage in virtual collaboration across disciplinary, functional and organizational boundaries to tackle complex, equivocal problems. To succeed they must be able to rapidly learn from others to integrate and apply knowledge; yet research has focused on the virtual environment not the individuals' collaborative needs in that environment. Drawing on collaborative elaboration learning theory, I hypothesize that when individuals elaborate their own knowledge by sharing it with others and are able to identify the perspectives of others, they will realize greater learning and performance as a result. Using Te'eni's (2001) model of IT design for virtual communication, I hypothesize that four collaborativetechnology enabled strategies support individuals' sharing diverse knowledge and understanding others' perspectives by reducing the cognitive complexity associated with performing these actions in synchronous and asynchronous collaborative contexts. Results from a multi-wave survey of individuals working virtually with others support the hypothesized model and validate the proposed impacts of collaborative technology support on individual learning processes. This research greatly advances our understanding of how individuals employ collaborative technology in a multi-dimensional way, and how doing so positively impacts their ability to integrate and apply knowledge toward complex tasks.

Title: Searching the usenet network for virtual communities of practice
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: A model of Internet-based Community of Practice (CoP) closely following Wenger's (1998) theory of CoPs is proposed. The model guided a systematic search of the Usenet discussion network; eleven online communities were identified as strongly displaying CoP-like traits. A survey of community members was used to assess the presence of the constructs in Wenger's theory. Four communities, evenly split between computer and non-computer topics, were assessed as Usenet-based CoPs because they exhibited all Wenger constructs. This provides evidence that extra-organizational CoPs can emerge spontaneously in the social areas of the Internet, and that CoPs are not inherently limited to face-to-face interaction.

Title: Rhythm and synchronization of firms' M&A and alliance behaviors: An entrainment view
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We extend the study of mergers & acquisitions and alliances initiatives to include a temporal perspe RHYTH focusing on when, how and under which conditions firms should accelerate or slow down their M&A anu alliance processes. Using a social entrainm|ent model, we explore the relationship between the temporal properties of rhythm and synchronization and firm performance. We found a curvilinear relationship between rhythm of strategic actions and performance. Establishing rhythm compatibility internally increases performance while external synchronization of rhythm with competitors does not. Our study opens a new window for firms to create competitive advantage, namely, managing strategic actions effectively against time.

Title: Perceived intergroup threat and the status-dominance relationship
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: High-status group members have been shown to adopt dominance-oriented cognitions and behaviors as a means of rationalizing or reinforcing their dominant position, but little research has investigated the boundary conditions of this phenomenon. In the present article, the authors suggest that perceived intergroup threat may moderate the relationship between status and social dominance orientation (SDO), at least among highly-identified group members. To test this hypothesis experimentally, university students were threatened by a rival institution (Study 1), and Democrats and Republicans were threatened by exposure to a leading Presidential candidate from the opposing political party (Study 2). Results provided support for the notion that high group status produces dominance under conditions of intergroup threat. The implications of these findings for research on status and threat are discussed, as are their potential applications to organizational settings.

Title: The trap of affiramtion: Hidden costs of de-escalating commitment through self-affirmation
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Escalation of commitment is fueled by the need to justify earlier decisions. Drawing on the motivated cognition literature, we examine how self-affirmation processes influence self-justification needs and thus affect escalation decisions. Study 1 demonstrated that affirming one's global values before recommitting resources reduced escalation. Study 2 found that whereas affirming traits that were irrelevant to an earlier poor decision reduced escalation, affirming decision-relevant traits ironically increased escalation. Finally, Study 3 demonstrated that whereas high self-esteem was associated with reduced escalation when primed following a poor decision, high self-esteem increased escalation when primed before making a poor decision. Across three studies, using three instantiations of self-affirmations and two measures of escalation, our results highlight the benefits and costs of using self-affirmation as a vehicle to de-escalate commitment; affirmations can either reduce self-justification needs by mobilizing resources for maintaining self-integrity or increase self-justification needs by highlighting self-standards that are not being met.

Title: The impact of information technology capabilities on alliance scope and performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Drawing on contractual and competence perspectives, this paper investigates the impact of firms' the information technology (IT) capabilities on the geographic scope and performance of strategic alliance. Results show that IT capabilities may either expand or shrink alliance scope, depending on the characteristics of the alliance task. Specifically, such capabilities expand alliance scope for ambiguous tasks and shrink alliance scope for highly analyzable tasks. We also find that IT capabilities generally enhance alliance performance, yet the performance impact of IT capabilities also depends upon alliance scope and task analyzability. We discuss the implications of these findings for the boundaries between the contractual and competence perspectives and suggest that task analyzability plays an important role in determining these boundaries for inter-organizational relationships.

Title: Venture capital syndications: Strategic networks for risk diversification or resources sharing?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: A syndication involving investors can be understood as a kind of alliance. The study analyses the rationale of venture capital syndication. It is based on the 2715 syndications carried out by venture capital investors in the US in 2003. The study challenges the mainstream in finance theory that explains syndication as a tool of risk management. By using the distinction between uncertainty and risk, the study points out that the contract of the first round of funding is used to socially embedded the relationship between investors and entrepreneurs in order to initiate a "learning by collaborating" process. Inside information owned by the primary investor is used as a gift to initiate reciprocal exchange by inviting other investors in syndication to fund following rounds. New investors bring not only financial capital to the entrepreneur but also other resources (technology, market, knowledge,...).

Title: Consensus and dissent: Fostering performance of new product development teams
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We develop a model to explain why fostering dissent potential (e.g., by increasing informational diversity) requires a concomitant enhancement of consensus potential (e.g., by promoting a win-win strategy) - and vice versa. Results obtained in a study of 37 new product development (NPD) teams partly confirmed our hypotheses. Given a high consensus potential (i.e., a pronounced win-win strategy), there was a positive relationship between dissent potential (i.e., informational diversity) and team performance. Moreover, when dissent potential (informational diversity) was low, there was a negative relationship between consensus potential (win-win strategy) and team performance. As expected, these relationships did not hold when age diversity was studied in lieu of informational diversity as an indicator of dissent potential.

Title: Cultural consumption and value creation in consumer goods technology industries
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Drawing on Bourdieu's theory of cultural capital I argue that consumption is in part an expression of cultural expertise, leading consumers to consume a wide range of products through aesthetic lens. I address the nature of producer activities that endow products conventionally viewed as tools, with art utilities that satisfy cultural consumption criteria.

Title: Institutional goverenance and market signals: Deceptive mimicry in Russia's post-communist banking industry
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We propose that foreign investors who do not account for local differences in governance systems c likely to rely on deceptive rather than accurate signals in transition economies. The weak nature of institutional governance systems in many transition markets increases the economic rewards to "deceptive mimicry," the imitation of the form of a market signal in the absence of substantive content. Under these conditions, the use of western-style signals may lead to consequences opposite to those desired. We test our propositions about the prevalence of deceptive mimicry in weak governance systems by looking at the characteristics of Russians banks that received foreign loans prior to the August 1998 financial crisis and the subsequent survival of the banks following the crisis. We show that Western investors relied on western-style signals to make investment decisions before the crisis, but it was exactly the banks that displayed these signals that were more likely to fail afterwards.

Title: Institutional isomorphism among indiana nonprofits: Measuring homogenization and formalization
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: According to neoinstitutional theory, organizations adopt the legitimating structures and procedures regardless of their impact on the rational efficiency and effectiveness of the organization's operations. This demonstrated legitimacy provides the organization with access to resources necessary for organizational survival, independent of gains in efficiency or effectiveness. In this paper, I develop a cross-sectional analysis of Indiana's nonprofit sector that examines the presence of institutional isomorphism among Indiana nonprofits. The analysis indicates evidence of homogenization of nonprofits within mission defined sub-sectors and that normative, mimetic, and coercive isomorphic pressures are driving the formalization of Indiana nonprofits. Title: Wealth, profit or sustainable advantage: Which should be the dependent variable for strategy?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In the literature of strategic management, most of the research on profitability focuses on conditions under which a firm can enjoy extraordinary profits in the long run, despite the efforts of its competitors.This familiar line of thinking is both extended and challenged in the present paper. Under the extension heading, we further clarify the sense in which idiosyncratic resources can be the economic basis of sustained profitability in long run equilibrium - even when that equilibrium is one that might be characterized in an economics textbook as purely competitive. We point out, however, that durable profitability based in sustained advantage is not the ultimate objective that firm owners and managers should want to pursue (and strategy scholars should want to study). Rather, they should be primarily interested in what happens to the wealth of the owners. Wealth creation, however, cannot be assessed in strictly in static or short-run terms. An intertemporal analysis is required because valuable idiosyncratic resources are typically the result of investments, and such investments are often widely separated in time from the quasi-rent streams that constitute their returns. We support and illustrate these arguments by exploring a model that is a simple Marshallian representation of competition in an evolving industry. The main themes are familiar ones of evolutionary economics; profits drive growth and more efficient firms drive out less efficient ones; imitation may permit the inefficient to become efficient. Our model departs from textbook economics in one key respect, but thereby converges with the "resource based view" (RBV) in strategic management: We posit not only that firms differ, but that this heterogeneity centrally involves idiosyncratic firm resources that are not simply the inputs that are available in the market. Rather, generic inputs are purchased in the market and are turned into resources specialized to the firm by virtue of sunk investments in a costly process of customization. Profits emerge (as a function of capability heterogeneity), and grow or erode over time as the industry evolves. We compute model trajectories under a wide range of conditions, and assess effects on wealth creation (as measured by net present value) as well as sustained profitability. We show that the relative importance of one-off customizing investments directly affects the ability to sustain profits, as well as to the extent to which firms of differential efficiency can co-exist in equilibrium. We also show that sustainable profits may be a relatively limited part of total industry wealth creation, and that adjustment paths of industry evolution affect both NPV and the equilibrium profits in a sector.

Title: Revisiting the agency theoretic view of capital structure
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Agency theorists contend that managers have a predilection for growing the firm beyond its optimal scale, and that the hard budget constraints and high powered incentives of debt can attenuate this problem. However, this view is incomplete because it fails to account for the fact that debt is heterogeneous, with some forms pre-committing to future courses of action while others retain the discretion to make intendedly rational and wise decisions in the future as conditions unfold. Viewing the heterogeneity 01 debt through the complementary lenses of the economic theory of rules versus discretion and the sociological theory of embeddedness suggests, quite paradoxically, that retaining the discretion to 'act optimally' in the future (as opposed to pre-committing to courses of action) can induce suboptimal outcomes. Specifically, the retention of lender discretion erodes one of the most noted governance properties of debt: its ability to discipline growth. Our empirical results support our contention that debt heterogeneity is an important source of firm heterogeneity that has a profound impact on both firm growth and the returns to growth.

Title: The origin of the network positions of new organizations: From whom are entrepreneurs likely to receive their first investments
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper examines the mechanisms by which organizations acquire their original network positions, or sets of partnerships. Although there has been significant research on the evolution of organizational network positions, how a new organization acquires its original network position has received more limited attention. I attempt to redress this imbalance using two competing logics, one based on inherited network and status positions and the other based on accomplishments. I test these logics in a study of venture capitalists and other investment organizations forming investment partnerships with (e.g., investing in) 92 Internet security ventures. In contrast to the literature on network position evolution, I find that a new organization's accomplishments play an important role in determining with whom it initially partners, while the influence of its inherited network and status positions quickly fade over time.

Title: Managerial-enacted empowerment: Dimensionality and effects on the wellbeing and performance of service workers
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Recognizing the potential conflict between operational pressures on the one hand and concerns with employee wellbeing on the other, we examine whether and how service employees' job discretion may be enhanced without harming operational efficiency. Viewing managerial-enacted empowerment as varying along two dimensions - namely (1) the depth of enacted empowerment or the degree to which the intervention is rhetorical (aiming to influence employees' sense of mastery, what we refer to as surface empowerment) as opposed to actual (aiming to influence the actual degree of employee task control, what we refer to as deep empowerment), and (2) the breadth of enacted empowerment or whether authority is allocated on the basis of equality or equity principles - we examine the relative efficacy of alternative empowerment initiatives in the context of two lab-based studies. The results of these studies highlight the advantages of deep over surface empowerment initiatives with respect to both employee wellbeing and performance, and indicate that the benefits of deep empowerment initiatives with regard to performance may be enhanced when such initiatives are applied on the basis of norms of equity.

Title: Rethinking institutional distance: Using neo-institutional theory to inform international management
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The concept of institutional distance has proved useful in highlighting the challenges faced by MNCs stemming from the differences between the institutional contexts of their home and host countries. In this article, we use three ideas from neo-institutional theory to expand and clarify this important concept: institutional uncertainty, organizational field, and institutional entrepreneur. The concept of institutional uncertainty highlights the fact that it is not just differences in the institutional arrangements that affect international business, but also the fact that some institutional contexts are not deeply institutionalized. The concept of an organizational field highlights the fact that the differences between home and host contexts are not uniform across entire business systems, and allows for a more fine-grained analysis of institutional distance. Finally, we draw on the rapidly developing literature on institutional entrepreneurship to point to the important role MNCs can play in the development of institutional arrangements.

Title: Research collaboration networks and innovation output
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper uses a longitudinal approach to examine the evolution of co-authorship networks of the firms in the biotechnology industry. We use social network theory to develop a model of the structure and dynamics of interorganizational research collaboration networks. Using novel longitudinal methods, this paper demonstrates how research collaboration networks in the biotechnology industry evolve and how this evolution affects focal firms' successive performance in terms of the firms' innovative output. The model is tested on a sample of 53 biotechnology firms over a span of 15 years (1990-2004). The results indicate significant effects of network size, network growth and inclusion of new members in the network on the research productivity of biotechnology firms. Moreover, our results reveal the significance of the management challenge presented by research networks, specifically indicating that growing networks by adding new and diverse members presents significant challenges for the managers of the firms in our study.

Title: Reactions to inequity as a function of organization strategy: Effect of micro and macro variables
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In an experimental study, we investigated the role of organizational context in explaining employees' reactions to a state of inequity. Specifically, we investigated employees' reactions to a state of inequity resulting from an organization's pursuit of its strategic goal to improve its competitive standing in its industry. We proposed and tested hypotheses on the moderating effects of duration of inequity, probability of strategic goal attainment, and interactional justice in explaining employees' reactions to the experience of inequity. Consistent with our hypotheses, the results revealed that these contextual variables helped explain the conditions under which individuals are likely to perceive a situation of inequity as more versus less fair. The results further indicated that organizational context can help explain seemingly conflicting reactions of individuals to inequity (i.e., perceiving the situation as fair, yet remaining uncommitted to the organization). Implications of the findings for theory and practice were also addressed.

Title: Mobile trust, enacted relationships: Social capital in a state-level policy network
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: What holds a policy network together? Our previous work on policy networks suggests that personal social capital, organizational social capital, and resource dependence are complementary bases for cohesion. In this paper we take up the challenge issued by Ibarra, Kilduff, and Tsai (2005: 359) to "bring the individual back in" to network studies by examining the dynamics between individual and organizational social capital, a process that has not been fully developed in the literature, and to tighten the connection between social capital and resource dependence. Although researchers acknowledge that personal social capital contributes to organizational social capital (Knoke, 1999; Burt, 1992), to our knowledge, no studies have examined how it contributes in a longitudinal, interorganizational policy network study. The first section of this paper discusses the policy network framework, social capital, and resource dependence. The second section reviews case selection and research methods. In the third section we present finding from our longitudinal case study of an adult basic education policy network between 1998 ("Wave 1") and 2005 ("Wave 2") in a state we have pseudonymed "Newstatia." Using the theory from the first section and the findings in section three, we weave together social capital and resource dependence to present the concept of "enacted interorganizational relationships." The last section concludes with directions for future research.

Title: The impact of environmental characteristics on firm performance: A meta-analysis
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The importance of environmental factors for firm performance has attracted a great amount of interest among strategic management scholars. Despite the large body of research on environmental characteristics, there is still a lack of consensus on conceptualization and measurement of environmental constructs. As a consequence, empirical results on their performance impact are controversial. We integrate past empirical work on the performance effects of environmental munificence, hostility, dynamism, and complexity through the method of meta-analysis. Our results indicate that munificence is positively associated with performance, whereas hostility, complexity and dynamism have small or even non-significant effects on firm success. Moderator analyses demonstrate that the magnitude of the effects depends on firm size as well as the application of archival vs. perceptual measures.

Title: Overqualified employees: Too good to hire or too good to be true?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Research has not clearly established whether overqualified employees are problematic in terms of lower job attitudes and performance and higher turnover or whether they can be effective organizational members. To address this issue, we studied 252 sales associates from 25 stores of a Turkish retail clothing chain. Our results show that hiring overqualified individuals may be a concern if not managed appropriately. We found negative main effects for these workers in terms of job satisfaction and intentions to remain. Conversely, overqualification was positively related to sales performance and unrelated to actual turnover. However, empowerment ameliorated the negative effects of overqualification on job satisfaction and turnover intentions such that those with high empowerment had no negative affects. Empowerment also moderated the relationship between overqualification and actual turnover 6 months later so that overqualified employees with low empowerment were more likely to leave than those who reported high empowerment.

Title: Corporate social responsibility: Institutional response to labor, legal and shareholder environments
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Corporate social responsibility (CSR) is widely regarded as the response of corporations to societal pressures with respect to social issues such as human rights and the environment. Much the way Burt (1983) argued that corporations use philanthropy as a marketing ploy, effectively "co-opting" their target audiences, we argue that CSR represents actively adopted strategies in response to the pressures corporations face in the local institutional environments in which they are embedded. We show that corporations have been aggressive in adopting CSR institutions and practices when they are (1) publicly traded, (2) in areas that are high in union density, and (3) are located in federal appellate jurisdictions that have been aggressive in their standards for protecting workers' rights. Drawing on research in neoinstitutional analysis in organizational sociology, we interpret these findings to indicate that corporations have responded to localized employment pressures by adopting strategies that allow them to appear legitimate in this realm. Specifically, corporations deal with pressures surrounding responsible employment practices by adopting the practices of the CSR regime.

Title: Why do some us firms link environmental performance to executive compensation? Does it matter?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Integrating ideas from agency theory and institutional theory, we develop a comprehensive model of determinants of the increasingly popular practice of linking executive compensation to environmental performance. We successfully test the model on a sample of US firms in the 1990s. We then test whether this explicit linkage impacts future environmental performance in these same firms and find that it does not for a range of environmental performance measures drawn from the KLD and IRRC databases. This raises the possibility that firms may be using the practice as a symbolic gesture rather than a substantive mechanism to effect change, perhaps even as a form of greenwashing. (106 words).

Title: Agency theory and the effects of cognitive social categorization
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Agency theorists examine relationships between principals and agents who have been contractually bound together. In this theoretical essay, we contribute to agency theory by integrating behavioral research with agency thinking in order to place these actors in a more socialized context. We examine how principals and agents use social categorization processes. We argue the outcomes of these processes are self-reinforcing, and shape the discretionary behaviors of principals and agents alike, thereby influencing agency costs and firm performance. It is our position that the integration of these social-cognitive perspectives to standard agency logic on principal-agent relationships has the potential to facilitate a more complete understanding of the causes of agency costs and the means through which these costs can be mitigated.

Title: How relevant is the MBA? Assessing the alignment of mba curricula and managerial competencies
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Masters of Business Administration (MBA) programs are being met with escalating criticism from academics, students and various organizational stakeholders. Central to these criticisms is the contention that the MBA is wholly out-of-touch with the "real-world" and is irrelevant to the needs of practicing managers. Examining this contention, the present study investigated the relevancy of MBA curricula in relation to managerial competency requirements. This study also sought administrators' perceptions of their own institution's ability to design and deliver a relevant MBA. Relying on an empirically derived competency model from incumbent managers (N = 8,633), results showed that the majority of business school curricula adequately covers key managerial competency requirements. However, across 373 schools, competencies indicated by managers to be most critical (i.e., managing human capital and managing strategy & innovation) are the very competencies least represented in MBA curricula. Findings also indicate that the more closely aligned an institution's curricula with managerial competencies, the more likely administrators are to report significant pressures to change or revise their curricula to actually be less relevant to managerial reality. Discussion is presented relevant to recent discourse regarding the purported legitimacy crisis in management education.

Title: Organizational performance, human resource investments, and employee attitudes
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We proposed a model in which employee attitudes were viewed both as antecedents and consequences of organizational performance. This model was tested utilizing employee-survey and objective organizational performance data from a sample of 127 publicly traded US organizations. We found that (a) past financial performance significantly predicted future employee-attitudes, (b) this relationship was fully mediated by the human resource investments made by the organization, and (c) employee attitudes, in turn, predicted future customer-evaluations of the quality of product/service offerings. We discuss the theoretical, research, and practical implications of these findings.

Title: Institutional targeting in patent enforcement
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We seek to advance research on the targeting of specific institutional venues by firms as part of their non- market strategies, specifically linking these institutional targeting decisions to the long tradition of scholarship on firm-environment fit. We propose a theory where firms choose between specialized and generic institutions based on the fit with their prior market strategy decisions, the characteristics of their competitors, and their own capabilities. Using data on patent enforcement against foreign importers, we find support both for the hypothesized determinants of institutional targeting, as well as the causal mechanism (expectations about dispute settlement) that drives institutional targeting strategies in some contexts. Our research provides a direct empirical test for the proposition that firms derive benefits from the integration of their market and non-market strategies. Our findings also highlight how patent strategies are closely linked to the non-market institutions that define the property rights entailed in patents.

Title: Firm-explicit human capital: Understanding the value of transferable firm knowledge in the labor marketplace
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: An executive's firm-specific human capital is argued to be a critical resource to the executive's current organization, but because of its lack of transferability, is of little value outside the firm. We argue that there exists a form of firm-based knowledge, which we term firm-explicit human capital, that is, in fact, transferable to competing firms, and that these firms will be willing to pay a premium to obtain it. Using a sample of over 9,000 executives, we show that executives switching to competing firms received increases to base pay greater than non-movers and those moving within or between industries. We suggest these increases are reflective of the differential value associated with various forms of executive- level human capital and we discuss the implications of our findings for future human capital research.

Title: Perceiving is believing: Negative affective events and relational models in supervisory relationships
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Little is known about why the supervisory/line management relationship is one of the most frequently cited causes of workplace negative emotions. Existing research on emotions at work provides some clues but ignores the role of relational context. Drawing on attachment theory, the present research investigated a model suggesting that employees hold differing relational models of their supervisory relationship in conjunction with global relational models that they bring with them to the workplace. Together, these relational models are associated with different perceptions and interpretations of supervisor behaviour, which in turn are associated with differences in emotional reactions. This framework was used to guide critical incident-style interviews with 24 nurses employed in a UK NHS Trust. Findings were broadly consistent the proposed framework and previous emotions research in non-supervisory contexts. The research highlights that in order to understand why negative emotions occur in supervisory relationships it is important to consider affective events occurring within the relationship as embedded within a historical relational context.

Title: Source-recipient knowledge complementarity: A framework of design absorption process in NPD
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The research fills a literature gap on the source knowledge and the process through which it is used by the recipient firm. Focusing on one specific type of source knowledge - design - and the combination patterns through which it is exploited in the New Product Development (NPD) process, we argue that the complementarity of the source and the recipient knowledge is a critical aspect of the absorption process and therefore of the NPD performance. Through an exploratory multi-case study grounded in the French clothing and construction industries, we propose a framework of absorptive capacity and NPD performance.

Title: Relative technological discontinuities: Insights from the identification of innovation regime shifts
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We conceptualize and measure technological discontinuities as regime shifts in the time path of innovation. We model innovative activity as being decomposable into predictable exploitive behavior, and less predictable breakthroughs. We argue that breakthroughs constitute the foundation to persistent changes in future economic activity, with some breakthroughs having greater impact than others. Rather than identifying technological discontinuities as binary events, we identify then as processes of relative shifts with varying magnitudes. We then study the relationship between the relative discontinuities and innovation outputs, and identify strong impact on the pace of innovation, the newness of knowledge used, and the direction of technological search.

Title: High-performance work systems, dynamic workforce alignment, and firm performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: There has been growing interest in demonstrating that human resource systems contribute to firm performance, yet limited research attention has been paid to how particular workforce attributes affect firm performance under changing workforce conditions. In this study, I examine the extent to which, and the conditions under which, workforce alignment positively affects firm performance. Results from a field study of 196 small businesses indicate that workforce alignment mediates the relationship between high- performance work system use and sales growth. Findings further suggest that firms that attain dynamic workforce alignment grow faster than firms that attain workforce alignment under stable workforce conditions.

Title: Empowerment and organizational citizenship: Moderation by culture in a multi-national sample
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper examines the relationship between empowering leadership, psychological empowerment, organizational commitment, and organizational citizenship behaviors (OCBs). A sample of 640 employees and their supervisors was obtained from a large hotel chain's properties in 18 countries. Results suggest that a model in which psychological empowerment mediates the relationship between empowering leadership and organizational commitment and OCBs fit the data well. In addition, cultural values associated with power distance moderated all relationships within the model such that the relationships were weaker for individuals who were high on the Schwartz (1992) values of power, conformity, and tradition.

Title: Distributed calculation: Mechanisms of risk arbitrage in a world of uncertainty
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The study of capital markets is currently defined by a debate between the orthodox and the behavioral finance literatures. Recently, this debate has evolved from individual decisionmaking to overall market processes such as arbitrage. Sociologically, both paradigms are subject to the same critique: the two provide a black-and-white, overly dichotomous view of economic knowledge and social interaction, and fail to conceptualize the mediating role of technology. We address these shortcomings and the broader debate on market processes with an ethnographic study of risk arbitrage. Arbitrageurs, we find, operate in an environment of Knightian uncertainty. They overcome their limited knowledge of the future through a social and material mechanism of "distributed calculation" that includes establishing social, cognitive, and technological associations to frame and debate with others about a future that is unknown. Our study adds to economic sociology by detailing how calculation itself is social, even in a exceptionally quantitative environment such as an equity derivatives trading room.

Title: The gender logic of executive compensation
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Studies examining women's upward mobility to the top executive positions in U.S. corporations find strong industry effects. Some industries seem to be more open to women than others. In this paper, we seek to derive an explanation for industry differences in representation of women among top executives. We theorize that industries have gender logics that facilitate women managers' access to top executive positions. In short, we propose that industries based in a logic of care and engaged in interactive service work or in the social reproduction of everyday life will be more open to women. We use data from S&P's Execucomp dataset to conduct an analysis of industry averages of women representation among top executives and find evidence for these propositions. In additional analysis, we also find that an industry's gender logic influences average industry executive compensation. We also find, however, that industries based in a profit of logic also facilitate women executive attainment.

Title: Both market and hierarchy: A formal theory of hybrid governance forms
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Governance theories typically envision a unidimensional continuum between markets and hierarchies, ignoring true hybrids that are market-like in some ways yet hierarchy-like in others. Our theory derives hybrids from cross-task synergies in a multi-task principal-agent model.

Title: Disentangling concepts: The role of affect in trust development and cooperation
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The importance of trust for cooperative exchange is highly contested across the disciplines of psychology, sociology and economics. Although researchers from sociology, psychology, and organizational theory assert that affect influences trust, the role of affect and specific emotions in trust development and cooperative endeavors has not been clearly delineated. We contend that because affect-for example, feeling of sympathy, guilt and gratitude-can motivate cooperation independently from trust, it is only through the joint examination of affect and trust that we can reconcile conflicting perspectives and understand the unique role of trust in cooperative endeavors. This paper proposes an affective model of trust and cooperation that seeks to disentangle affect from trust and explicate the cognitive, motivational, and behavioral paths through which general affect and specific emotions influence both trust and cooperation. By arguing that trust is only a partial mediator of the impact of affect on cooperation, we attempt to provide the missing variable that begins to explain when and why scholars who contend trust is irrelevant are likely to make this assertion..

Title: Doing well by doing good: Objective findings, subjective assumptions, or selective amplification?
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study examines publication outlet as a contingency of the relationship between corporate social performance (CSP) and corporate financial performance (CFP). The meta-analytic moderator analysis, based on a total sample size N of 33,878 observations, suggests that disciplinary backgrounds of researchers, reviewers, and editors may influence findings. In economics, finance, and accounting journals, the average correlations found were only about half the value reported by SIM/business ethics journals (mean observed correlation coefficient r(obs) = .11 vs. 25, respectively; mean corrected correlation coefficient rho = .22 vs. .49, respectively). On average, (1) economists generally did not find null or negative CSP-CFP correlations and (2) findings reported in general management outlets (r(obs) = .21; rho = .41) were closer to SIM/business ethics results than those reported by economics, finance, and accounting researchers. The findings, which qualify previous meta-analytic conclusions in important ways, are consistent with studies highlighting selective amplification in the manuscript review process and, more broadly, with sociology-of-science explanations.

Title: A multidimensional framework for studying money in organizations
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Even in the age of such phenomena as backdated options, hedge fund hegemony and the marketization of virtually everything, money is under-theorized in management theory, represented as uninteresting or "inert" (Mitchell & Mickel, 1999). This "emptiness" contrasts with the rich treatment accorded money management's "sister" disciplines of economics, sociology, psychology and anthropology and it forecloses potentially fruitful avenues of organizational analysis. Insights from these disciplines are used as the basis for a new, multidimensional framework for analyzing money as a social construct. It is proposed that the framework can be used to illuminate important organizational practices and discourses.

Title: From dynamical patterns to developmental motors: Linking mathematical orders and process theories
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Although resource allocation provides an indication of the strategy formation process within an organization, it has been mainly investigated in connection with particular events (e.g. business exits, ventures) and on a single cases basis. No research efforts have been conducted to detect and understand the underlying dynamical patterns (i.e., the general boundaries and tendencies) which offers insights on the overall developmental motors (i.e., the general causal mechanisms) in organizations. The paper analyzes the resource allocation patterns of global multi-business firms which differ in their forms of organizing (de-/centralization) and their environmental context (high/low turbulence) within a coherent strategic period. Mathematical and stochastic modeling tools are used to differentiate between stable, periodic, chaotic, pure random and coloured noise patterns. Results indicate deterministic patterns of resource allocation for centralized organizations and random patterns for decentralized organizations as well as a higher complexity with increasing environmental turbulence. Based on theory and these results, different developmental motors are identified (i.e. teleological, evolutionary, life-cycle, and dialectical motor) which account for the detected dynamical patterns. Knowledge of these patterns and their developmental motors improves our understanding of resource allocation in organizations and offers insights for corporate level managers on how to align strategy approaches, organizational structures, and resource allocation within different environments.

Title: Extending strategic management's reach: Towards a resource investment explanation for firm existence
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper argues that the field of strategic management needs to develop its own explanation for why firms exist because it must explain why some firms can persistently outperform other firms, which infers an explanation for firm competitiveness and, in turn, why firms exist. It is no longer helpful to just focus on why firms are different to markets. To this end, we develop the idea that firms exist for a multitude of reasons, depending on the particular institutional perspective taken, but if one is to explain heterogeneous firm performance, these reasons can be reduced to one explanation of firm existence: that firms predominantly exist to satisfy the payment demands of their owners. This approach has the potential to describe how the resource investments of different firms drive the economy.

Title: Not too big and not too small: Identifying the 'sweet spot' for nonprofit boards
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Determining an appropriate size for a board of directors remains an ongoing challenge for which existing research has provided little practical guidance. Our study attempts to redress this gap by deconstructing the complexity, both theoretically and methodologically, inherent within exploring the relationship between board size and financial performance. While previous studies examining this relationship have almost exclusively drawn upon samples comprised of large, U.S. for-profit organizations, we attempt to broaden the existing boundary conditions of current theory by developing and testing propositions within the context of a diverse set of Canadian nonprofit organizations.

Title: Stakeholder theory and managerial discretion
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: There is a natural tension in stakeholder research between the desire to create managerial theory, which recommends practices for managing firm-stakeholder relationships, and the acknowledgment that some powerful stakeholder groups can constrain managerial choice altogether. Stakeholder researchers often ignore this tension and assume high levels of managerial discretion. Here, we relax this assumption, assume instead that managerial discretion varies across firms, and explore stakeholder management's short-term effects on performance and long-term effects on future discretion.

Title: Entrepreneurial strategy narratives and resource acquisition in IPOs
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In this paper we examine the impact of storytelling on an entrepreneurial firm's ability to acquire resources. Drawing on the cultural entrepreneurship and organizational discourse literature, we investigate the effects of several narrative devices: identity constructions and persuasive appeals, familiarity and unfamiliarity, and elaboration and consistency. Our analyses of the IPO prospectuses issued between 1996-2000 by firms in three high-tech industries (semiconductors, biotechnology and internet content providers) provides strong support for the importance of appropriately-crafted narratives as a resource-leveraging tool. The impact of storytelling is particularly pronounced for entrepreneurial ventures with lower resource levels and those in less mature industries.

Title: Lying in the bed that you make: How subordinates monitor supervisors' efforts to promote fairness
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We argue that subordinates develop expectations about specific types of fairness commensurate with the managerial controls they encounter and exhibit higher levels of job satisfaction when managers fulfill their fairness expectations. In a series of survey analyses, we observe that subordinates who encounter market controls conduct distributive fairness monitoring, subordinates who encounter bureaucratic controls conduct procedural fairness monitoring, and subordinates who encounter clan controls conduct interpersonal fairness monitoring. We also observe that managers who effectively attend to their subordinates' fairness expectations promote higher levels of aggregate subordinate job satisfaction than those who do not.

Title: Governanace and performance of IPOs: The impact of private equity investors and legal institutions
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Although agency theory argues that there is a direct relationship between ownership patterns and performance, the empirical evidence to date has been mixed. However, previous studies have focused on samples of large mature firms in a single country. Combining agency and institutional perspectives, this paper examines performance effects of two types of private equity investors (venture capitalists and business angels) and ownership concentration in firms that have recently undergone an IPO in the UK and France. Using a unique, hand-collected dataset of 242 matched IPOs in the two countries, it argues that legal institutions can moderate the effects of different types of owners and ownership concentration on performance. Our findings support the argument that concentrated ownership impacts performance, but this effect is stronger in France. Second, it is shown that the two types of private equity investors have a differential impact on performance, but this impact is found to be influenced by the legal institutions in the given country.

Title: Organizational unit ACAP: Social context and performance outcomes
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper conceptualizes on an organizational unit's ACAP, and examines its relationships with several interpersonal conditions, knowledge-oriented outcomes, and performance consequences. In a sample of 93 marketing divisions from the Greek ICT, pharmaceutical and food industry, we develop a measure of unit's ACAP -defined as the ability to acquire, assimilate, and integrate new knowledge-, examine the determining role of several interpersonal unit characteristics (i.e., social interaction, trust, and shared vision), and test both the knowledge and performance effects of the absorptive capacity construct. The results of a structural model, through path analysis, provided support for all the hypothesized relationships, thus broadening our understanding of the conditions under which absorptive capacity may lead to knowledge and performance outcomes.

Title: Prioritization in computer-mediated communication: Influences of urgency, notification, and identity
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Communication is critical for accomplishing work in today's knowledge organizations. And computer mediated forms of communication such as instant messaging are ever increasing in their prevalence as methods for communicating on the job. However, we do not yet have a good understanding of how people make decisions when switching their attention between incoming instant messaging communications and ongoing work tasks, or when prioritizing certain messages over others. In this paper we present a model of communication that incorporates factors influencing the decision to initiate and respond, and the impacts of communication interactions on both sender and receiver. Results from two laboratory studies confirm our hypothesis that giving the receiver control over communication timing can benefit the receiver. However, such a design can negatively impact the communication sender because of delayed response and unanswered messages. The studies advance previous work by showing how visibility of sender's task state and a common social identity affect communication decisions. Our results show that receiver's use information about the sender's relative information needs in prioritizing communication for response, and prioritize senders with a common social identity regardless of how busy they are when communication arrives.

Title: Are high-power teams high performers? Linking team power to trust, interpersonal congruence, and decision-making performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: In this study, we compare the performance of high-power organizational teams to low-power organizational teams on a decision making task. We find that low-power teams outperform high-power teams, and that this effect is fully explained by the lower levels of intragroup trust present in high-power teams. Results show that the relationship between team power and intragroup trust is moderated by interpersonal power congruence, such that when high-power team members agree on the relative power of each of their teammates, the relationship between team power and intragroup trust is more positive.

Title: Initiating divergent organizational change: The enabling role of actors' social position
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study addresses the paradox of embedded human agency, or the contradiction between actors' agency and institutional determinism. It helps to resolve this paradox by considering the enabling role of actors' social position. Adopting a relational view of human agency, I develop a model about the impact of actors' social position on their likelihood to initiate organizational changes that diverge from the existing institutions. I test this model using data from ninety-three change projects each conducted by a clinical manager from the National Health Service (NHS) in the United Kingdom between 2002 and 2004. Findings suggest that actors' social position is an important enabling condition for divergent organizational change and that the type of divergent organizational change an actor undertakes depends on his or her social position. The positional characteristics of the actors who are more likely to initiate each type of divergent organizational change are radically different.

Title: Resource stocks, innovation & persistent heterogeneity
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Many strategy scholars believe that Variance in competitors' resources and capabilities largely determine differences in firm performance. It also is widely accepted that when conditions exist to isolate a firm's resources and capabilities from imitation, advantages associated with these factors may translate into sustained differences in performance. Given the importance of these assumptions, it is surprising how little empirical research exists on these topics. Instead, the fragmented empirical work often investigates how resources and/or capabilities increase or decrease performance or survival chances rather than how these factors contribute to enduring and systematic performance differences among close rivals (Hoopes et al, 2003; exceptions, Villalonga, 2004; Roberts & Dowling, 2002). This paper offers empirical evidence regarding the association between a firm's capability-enabling resource stocks and persistent differences in the superior performance and innovation activity of firms competing in the global semiconductor industry between 1990 -1999. Our analysis finds that innovation activity is associated with persistent above average firm profits. We also compare the durability of different resource stocks to understand which stocks might assist a firm in sustaining its lead in innovation activity relative to industry competitors. We find that advantages associated with a firm's patent stock and with the experience held by a firm's partners erode at a faster rate than advantages associated with a firm's cumulative production experience.
