Title: Organizational routines as alliance capabilities: The missing link
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Strategic alliances continue to increase in popularity. However, a large number of such alliances are deemed to be unsuccessful. Interestingly, the success of strategic alliances differs considerably between firms. Thus, organizational factors seem to be responsible for the observed performance heterogeneity. Extant research on organizational level antecedents of alliance performance has mainly focused on factors such as alliance experience and alliance structures, with diverging results. Building on the literature on dynamic capabilities and learning curve effects, this study proposes that alliance capability, composed of alliance management routines, is a key mediator of the performance impact of both alliance experience and alliance structures. Based on survey data from 302 firms, the research model is tested using structural equation modeling. The results demonstrate a valid measurement of a five-dimensional model of alliance capability, manifested in the routines of inter-organizational coordination, alliance portfolio coordination, inter-organizational learning, alliance proactiveness, and alliance adaptation. In addition, there is evidence of a mediating effect of the alliance capability construct. We conclude that failure to include alliance management routines may lead to an imprecise understanding of the performance impact of alliance experience and alliance structures.
Index Keywords: Enterprise resource management; Alliances; Dynamic capabilities; Inter-organizational coordinations; Inter-organizational learning; Learning curve effect; Mediation; Organizational factors; Structural equation modeling; Industrial management

Title: When supplier ethical policies matter to a buyer (Or don't): The moderating role of switching cost
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Drawing on signaling theory, we suggest that a supplier's ethical policies influence the buyer's trust in the supplier, which, in turn, generates commitment to that supplier. We draw on side-bet theory to suggest that switching costs moderate these relationships and also determine when supplier ethical policies factor into the buyer's decision to commit to a supplier. We empirically test our model with survey data from 158 purchasing managers within three manufacturing industries. Results confirm the connection between ethical policies and commitment, but suggest that a supplier's ethical policies matter less when switching suppliers is perceived as too costly.
Index Keywords: Decision theory; Management; Sales; BET theory; Ethics; Inter-organizational; Manufacturing industries; Signaling theory; Survey data; Switching costs; Philosophical aspects

Title: The mediating role of overall fairness and the moderating role of trust certainty in justice-criteria relationships: Testing fundamental tenets of fairness heuristic theory
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Fairness heuristic theory (Lind, 2001) proposes that perceptions of overall fairness are (a) influenced by information pertaining to different types of justice, (b) more proximal predictors of responses relative to specific types of justice, and (c) used to infer trust, especially under conditions of uncertainty. In Study 1 (N = 1,340), support was found for the mediating role of overall fairness in the relationships between specific types of justice and employee attitudes. These mediated effects were replicated in Study 2 (N = 881), and the effect of overall fairness on trust in senior management was moderated by trust certainty.
Index Keywords: Employee attitudes; Fairness; Fairness heuristic theory; Justice; Mediating roles; Senior management; Behavioral research

Title: Investigating the relationships between presentation of self and contributions to an electronic network of practice
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Electronic Networks of Practice (NoPs) refer to web-based environments in which people who share similar occupational practices can discuss and access peers' experiences and expertise without necessarily interacting with them offline. Because most members of electronic NoPs only know each other through electronic ties, they assess their peers' expertise through their online front. How participants present themselves is thus likely to impact the dynamics that take place within an electronic NoP. This research examines the relationships between how participants present themselves and how they participate in electronic NoPs. To do so, an electronic NoP related to banking was investigated. The profiles of a sample of 180 participants and a related sample of more than 1670 messages was collected and interpreted. Results show a constructed consistence between the profiles adopted by participants and the messages they post. Different categories of profiles emerged from the data and were significantly related to different types of contributions. Moreover, while the electronic NoP was growing at a fast pace, very few new participants adopted the behavior of active contributors, casting a shadow onto the future of the electronic NoP. This research contributes to the understanding of behaviors in virtual environments and of the temporal dimension of these behaviors. Implications of this research for the research and management of electronic NoPs and knowledge management are suggested.

Title: The positive side of reorganization: Interactive effects of job changes and role perceptions
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Much of the prior work examining employee reactions to large-scale organizational changes has emphasized the role of contextual and implementation factors. In this study we looked at the role of job content (as opposed to context) factors in explaining employee responses to a company reorganization. More specifically, we looked at how employees reframed their jobs in the new organization (enriching versus enlarging), the degree of change, and the impact of role-related variables (role ambiguity, role overload) in explaining work attitudes and behaviors.

Title: LMX and work outcomes: The mediating role of delegation in the Malaysian business context
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The present study addresses the call for empirical examinations of the relationship between leader- member exchange (LMX) and delegation and their impact on work-related outcomes. It contributes to the leadership literature by linking the two bodies of knowledge, testing the mediating role of delegation between LMX and work outcomes. Data were collected from 215 employees and their 94 different immediate supervisors representing various manufacturing and service organizations in northern Malaysia. Supervisors rated leader-member exchange (LMX-L) and organizational citizenship behavior (OCB) scale items, whereas subordinates rated LMX-M, perceived delegation, and affective commitment scale items. Results showed that perceived delegation fully mediated the relationship between LMX-L and organizational commitment and between LMX-M and OCB-altruism and OCB-conscientiousness. Practical implications of the study findings and directions for future research are discussed.

Title: An efficient frontier in organization design
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: this paper presents a method to analyze a broad range of decision-making organizational forms that lie between the hierarchy and the polyarchy. The metho|d predicts Type I and II errors, speed, cost, and proportion of good projects approved for each organizational form. The model has far reaching implications, as all organizations have to decide how centralized or decentralized they are going to be. One important result is that not all organizations are efficient; some organizational forms should always be preferred over others. Some implications of the model are discussed in light of the organization design and the innovation literature.

Title: What kind of organizations do protean people prefer? The case of Germany and the United States
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Hall (1996) has said that the careers of the century will be "protean." Protean career actors are selfdirected and driven by personal values. This presents a paradox as organizations have traditionally demanded loyalty to institutional values and rewarded performance compliant with organizational (not necessarily individual) goals. Nevertheless, few organizations can afford to lose talent, including talented protean employees. This raises the question of what sort of organizations will attract protean employees. In this study, we explore the link between a protean career orientation and organizational preferences in Germany and the United States. 531 Students at various stages of university were surveyed in both countries. Protean German and U.S. students both indicated a preference for cultures allowing autonomy and innovation, but differed according to certain job orientations - such as leisure preference. Implications for research and practice are discussed.
Index Keywords: Career orientations; Careers; Person-organization fit; Self-directed; Values; Personnel

Title: Social capital and competitive behavior: A study of interfirm networks and rivalry among automakers
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper explores how the differential access to network resources influences firms' competitive behavior in the automobile industry. Specifically, we explore how the capability of firms to compete with a greater number and variety of competitive actions is influenced by the changes in the access to both the structural and relational aspects of social capital. The structural aspect of the social capital is depicted by the network centrality and structural autonomy of the firms in the network, whereas the relational aspect is approximated by the functional variety of the alliance types (e.g., R&D, marketing, manufacturing, finance, distribution, etc.). Our empirical investigation showed that the diversity of the alliance types is positively related to the firms' ability to compete more intensively and with a wide variety of action types. Our findings suggest that it is the diversity and the non-redundancy of the ties with network partners (rather than the total number of alliances) that are most critical for an automaker's ability to out-compete rivals.
Author Keywords: Austrian economics; Competitive dynamics; Interorganizational networks

Title: Threats to validity and reliability in longitudinal case study TIMELINES
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Management researchers rely on longitudinal case studies to investigate a variety of processes such as strategy and planning development, organizational change, and industry dynamics. Yet, virtually no attention has been paid to understanding the unique threats to validity and reliability involved in reconstructing a chronology of events and characteristics based on first-person recounts and historical records. In this article, we (1) identify three common types of longitudinal case study designs, (2) identify the unique validity and reliability issues associated with each type, and (3) propose methods for addressing each of the four threats. Our discussion is grounded in a comparative analysis of 52 studies that use the longitudinal case study design published in leading journals between 2001 and 2005. We identify and discuss three specific threats to case study timeline validity - recall effect, spoiler effect, longitudinal selection bias - and also identify and discuss a unique reliability constraint - the reliability of a reconstructed event timeline.

Title: Knowledge sharing in organizations: Inviting ethics and emotion to the banquet
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We propose an organization-level model that links distinctive elements of philosophical orientation (practical wisdom) and emotion management (emotional capability) to show how ethics and emotion can interact to influence knowledge sharing in organizations. We view top executives as creators of the organizational context that encourages development and diffusion of ethical and emotional norms and middle managers as adjusting the application of these norms to the local context. Varying effectiveness in top executives' context creating and middle managers' context adjusting can produce different qualities of authenticity and speed in knowledge sharing in organizations. We discuss the implications of our theorizing in regard to the literatures on organizational learning and silence, ethics, and emotion management.
Author Keywords: Emotion management; Knowledge sharing; Practical wisdom

Title: Examining thinking style, EQ, and organizational commitment in the context of emotional labor
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Data from 93 managers demonstrated that linear thinking is associated with understanding and regulating emotions, nonlinear thinking is related to utilizing emotions to facilitate thinking, and balanced linear/nonlinear thinking is associated with overall emotional intelligence. Emotional labor interacted with balanced linear/nonlinear thinking to explain unique variance in affective organizational commitment.

Title: Extracting value from client relationships: Expertise and cross-selling in the UK legal market
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: How do suppliers capture the value they create with their clients? In this paper, I empirically examine the role of two drivers of suppliers' value capture for supplier profitability and buyer-supplier relationship stability. The first driver is the distinctiveness of suppliers' expertise compared to what their clients can get from competitors. The second driver is the realization of client-based scope economies through cross- selling. I analyze a unique longitudinal data set from the UK corporate legal market that comprises the client relationships of the largest UK law firms with FTSE 250 corporations, experts' assessment of law firms' capabilities, and law firms' profitability. I find that superior expertise relative to direct competitors and cross-selling, both by a focal firm and by its competitors, are important drivers of supplier profitability and client relationship stability. Moreover, cross-selling appears to be an important source of differentiation that also has a direct impact on competitors' ability to capture value. Overall, these findings contribute to our understanding of how competition and firm heterogeneity interplay to affect firm performance.

Title: A taxonomy of small firm technology commercialization
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper proposes a taxonomy of a very unusual set of small, highly innovative firms that disproportionately contribute to technological and industrial change in the US economy. We defined a population of serial innovators - firms with fewer than 500 employees, that are independent and long- lived, are not bankrupt and have at least 15 utility patents assigned to them in the 5-year period preceding 2002 - who operate across industries and use a variety of technology platforms. We empirically verified the existence of six of the seven proposed business models and associated technology commercialization strategies: 1. Research Organization or Contractor; 2. Science-based firms; 3. Highly specialized component supplier; 4. Specialized subcontractor firm; 5. Product Solutions providers; and 6. Service Solutions providers.

Title: Measuring strategic and internal fit in HRM: An alternative approach
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Although the 'best fit' approach in HRM is theoretically convincing, to date there is still a lack of empirical support and no agreement among academics on the operationalization of the two most widely used types of fit, strategic and internal fit. In this paper, we develop alternative ways to measure these fits, which cover the complexity of the constructs. Moreover, we introduce adaptation as a dynamic component to strategic and internal fit. We use case study data from two organizations in a retail setting to illustrate the proposed measurement approach and conclude with an evaluation of these operationalizations.
Index Keywords: Best fit; Dynamic component; Retail settings; Strategy; Use-case; Human resource management

Title: A typology for capturing the heterogeneity of family firms
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Using the configurational approach, this article develops a typology of family firms by aligning family values, extent of family involvement in business, and governance efficiencies. Family values regarding property rights and the role of business in family are used. Four modes of family involvement in both ownership and management - ranging from individual owner-manager to a combination of family and non-family owners-managers, lead to a typology of sixteen categories of family firms. Governance mechanisms likely to be effective in each of these family firm types are discussed leading to propositions for future research.
Index Keywords: Family firms; Governance; Governance mechanisms; Property right; Typology; Managers

Title: In the club: Human and social capital of leaders in free and open source software communities
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Free and open source software communities, which are free of many classical management structures and ordinary practices of planning represent a novel of organizing innovative work that is attracting the interest of an increasing number of scholars. These communities have varying structures that allow them to cope with problems of governance, coordination, representation and decision-making. How do some individuals within these communities make it to the positions of club of leaders and the decision makers in these communities? Much of the earlier research argues that these types of communities operate in a meritocratic manner and human capital, such as technological skills influence who becomes leaders. I bring to the fore how social capital, in addition to human capital, influences leadership. Relying on a longitudinal multi-method study of GNOME, a free and open source software community, I provide evidence on the role of human and social capital in influencing who becomes a leader. I provide insights into why some individuals graduate through the process of becoming an elected leader by analyzing several of the steps in this process. The results suggest that both the human capital and social capital is initially important, but that the role of human capital disappear further into the process of being elected. I discuss the implications of these results for theory and practice.

Title: Organizing open innovation: The role of competences, modularity, and performance integration
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Innovation increasingly takes place in networks, a fact that has been captured under the term 'open innovation'. Innovating firms have had to adapt to this situation. As it turns out, doing so is not always simple. While several business models, organization structures and management systems have been applied, the question what firms need to do in order to benefit from 'open innovation' is not yet fully answered. The research question we tackle in this paper is the following: which organization structure and management system to choose internally in order to be successful in innovating in an 'open innovation' situation? To date, only few papers deal with the specific issue of how to organize the external sourcing of technology and what are the organizational characteristics and competences firms have to possess in order to implement it successfully. The empirical material we present reports on the struggle of an important OEM in the automotive industry to implement an open innovation strategy, and how it restructured its processes and competences in order to do so successfully. We analyze why the OEM under scrutiny has encountered many problems in acting as a system integrator, and how it has learned from mistakes it had committed. Finally, based on the evidence of the case, we develop insights on what OEMs should focus on when implementing an open innovation strategy, and indications on the organizational and managerial means to do it.

Title: A revised and extended theory of the focused factory
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Why do we still not have an adequate explanation to account for the fact that a significant portion of factories are unfocused? Our response to the question is that we do not have an explanation, because we lack a formal and comprehensive theory of focus that is built on a coherent set of assumptions and takes relevant contingencies into account. In this paper, we elaborate on Skinner's original ideas of focus and formalize a theory of focus that is more general in scope and makes less restrictive assumptions. Theoretical propositions are preliminarily examined in a sample of 238 manufacturing plants in 8 countries and 3 industries. We find that there is a time and a place for the focused factory and that the performance implications of focus are not as straightforward as the received view suggests.

Title: Acquisition vs. internal development as entry modes for new business development: The dynamics of firm-market relevance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper addresses a long-standing empirical puzzle in the relationship between entry mode and firm-market relatedness. By making the distinction between entries inside versus outside a firm's primary business domain, we help to resolve the ambiguity in prior work on choices of entry mode (acquisition versus internal development).

Title: Foreign market entry choice, social capital, and liabilities of foreignness: A conceptual framework
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Within the last decade, the world's economies have experienced a tremendous proliferation of equit torei- based foreign market entries by multinational corporations, such as international acquisitions, international joint ventures, and international greenfield investments. With this development, an important stream in academia has emerged investigating the liabilities of foreignness (LOF) foreign-owned subsidiaries face in local markets. Extant research on the topic has provided valuable insights into the existence and performance implications of LOF. This paper extends this work by (a) systematically introducing an entry mode choice perspective into the liabilities of foreignness literature, (b) identifying three types of liabilities of foreignness, and (c) advancing an integrated framework of the impact of these types of LOF on alternative foreign market entry modes. It is further conceptualized that social capital constitutes a valuable resource available to an MNC to overcome liabilities of foreignness inherent in culturally and institutionally distant markets. In so doing, this paper provides a new perspective on liabilities of foreignness and thus contributes to more theoretical pluralism in the literature on the topic.

Title: Institutional entrepreneurship and the transformation of the global air navigation regime
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: How do global regulatory and technological environments change? The entrepreneurial aspects of institutional transformation have hitherto received very limited attention. This study elaborates the essential role that institutional entrepreneurs play in shifting an internationally accepted regime of regulation, technology, and managerial practice from one stable state to another. The activities of institutional entrepreneurs are theorized in terms of Hayekian, Kirznerian, and Schumpeterian conceptions of entrepreneurship. Each conception varies in terms of entrepreneurial agency, which is defined as the capacity for creative, willful and non-routine action. The perspective is illustrated through the case of the Civil Air Navigation System Organization (CANSO) and its role in transforming the global air navigation regime in the recent decade.

Title: The surprise of candor; Employee cynicism and technological change in late modernity work
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: As an attitude characterized by frustration, hopelessness, betrayal and disillusionment (Andersson, 1996; Wanous et al. 1994) employee cynicism or organizational cynicism could be considered as both a general and specific attitude of interest to the research of information system (IS) implementations. Today a broad literature body has emerged within the IS research community investigating the organizational consequences of IS implementations breaking with the technical/rational tradition of the IS field. This article explores the relationship between employee cynicism and technological change and is based on a longitudinal case study of a Swedish customer service centre. The article reveals the challenges, criticism and cynicism among highly educated customer service centre employees going through a IS implementation process. We found two groups of users with distinct features: one group which had strong IS literacy yet expressed modest motivation and commitment towards work; another group which had strong work competence yet significant antipathy towards technological and organizational change. We conclude that cynicism represents an important but neglected aspect of IS implementation outcomes. More so, cynics may be important players in successfully implementing new IS.

Title: Escalating commitment in group decision making
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We attempt to explain and predict the behavior of groups which have launched important initiatives that over time increasingly appear to be failing. We suggest that whether negative feedback results in escalation or withdrawal is contingent on the efficacy perceptions of the decision making group. When efficacy perceptions are unduly high, groups will be initially motivated to persist despite evidence of the perils of so doing. High collective efficacy may also vitiate the quality of the group decision making process. If so, the initial desire to escalate will not only likely survive the decision making process, but may also be heightened by it. Implications of this approach for management theory, research, and practice are discussed.

Title: The importance of being 'something': Identity centrality and work outcomes in off-shored call centers in India
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Existing studies of identity dynamics have shown that employees embody multiple social identities, and have multiple foci of identifications at work that shape their attitudes and behaviors. However, there remains an urgent need to extend these frameworks to the context of emergent global workplaces. In this paper, we focus on one such significant instance of contemporary globalization: the transnational service work in the international call center industry in India. Here we explore how national identity, religious identity and occupational identity centralities affect outcomes such as employee performance, intention to leave, stress and burnout over and above those engendered by organizational identification (OI). In our findings national identity centrality emerges as the most important predictor of outcomes as a main effect, and also the variable that significantly moderates the relationship of OI with performance and burnout. We also find some additional support for organizational identification and occupational identity centrality.

Title: The market value of patents and R&D: Evidence from european firms
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This paper provides novel empirical evidence on the private value of patents and R&D in a sample of firms from five European countries in the period 1985-2005. We explore the relationship between firm's Tobin's q, defined as the ratio of market value to the replacement value of firm's physical assets, and patents, accounting for the 'quality' of patents granted by the European Patent Office (EPO). We find that Tobin's q is positively and significantly associated with R&D and patent stocks. Given the increasing importance of software patents in the EPO, we tested for the impact of software patents on the market value of the firm and did not find any significant effect, in contrast to results for the United States.

Title: Learning fast: Understanding MBA internship effectiveness
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: MBA internships are brief work roles that are important for MBA learning and employment. I use role theory and goal theory to predict self-reported learning as one indicator of effectiveness for an MBA internship. Clear task role outputs (work deliverables and standards) early in the internship explained 15.7% of the variance in learning. A significant 3-way Task Output Clarity X Autonomy X Prior Experience interaction explained 4.5% of the variance. Contrary to prediction, less experienced interns learned most with clear task role outputs/low autonomy, and least with unclear task role outputs/low autonomy.

Title: Innovating knowledge communities
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: A useful level of analysis for the study of innovation may be what we call "knowledge communities" - intellectually cohesive, organic inter-organizational forms. Formal organizations like firms are excellent at promoting cooperation, but knowledge communities are superior at fostering collaboration - the most important process in innovation. Rather than focusing on what encourages performance in formal organizations, we study what characteristics encourage aggregate superior performance in informal knowledge communities in the technical field of computer science. Specifically, we explore the way knowledge communities both draw on past knowledge, as seen in citations, and use rhetoric, as found in writing, to seek a basis for differential success. We find that when using knowledge, successful knowledge communities draw from a broad range of sources and are extremely flexible in changing and adapting. In marked contrast, when using rhetoric, successful knowledge communities tend to use very similar vocabularies and language that does not move or adapt over time and is not unique or esoteric compared to the vocabulary of other communities. A better understanding of how inter-organizational collaborative network structures encourage innovation is important to understanding what drives innovation and how to promote it.
Index Keywords: Networks (circuits); Clustering; Collaborative network; Inter-organizational; Knowledge communities; Technical fields; Knowledge management

Title: Technical spirituality at work: Jacques ellul on workplace spirituality
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We assess the current state of workplace spirituality from the philosophical perspective of Jacques Ellul and show how the workplace spirituality movement has not escaped the infiltration and pervasiveness of technique. First, we describe Ellul's notion of technique and his critique that technique has become dominant, becoming an end in itself and subsuming all other ends as means in support of technique. We then demonstrate how the workplace spirituality movement presently displays the hallmarks of technique in its quest for results and facts, in its use of experts, and in the broadening and hence dissolution of the notion of spirituality. However, the dominance of technique has not gone unnoticed in the workplace spirituality movement. We highlight several scholars who have raised concerns and critiques of the movement in its technical form. Having noted the predominance of technique as well as its critique from some quarters, we suggest some possibilities for moving toward an authentic spirituality at work followed by some implications for undertaking scholarly research on workplace spirituality that explicitly recognizes technical dominance in spirituality. In conclusion we note that the logic of technique is firmly in place, and that it represents a formidable opponent to the practice of authentic spirituality in the workplace. It is incumbent upon those of us involved in workplace spirituality to resist its domination and find ways of fostering authenticity in spirituality at work.
Index Keywords: Jacques ellul; Scholarly research; Technique; Workplace spirituality; Philosophical aspects

Title: Transformational leadership, positive psychological traits, and firm performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: This study examined the positive psychological traits of hope and optimism, transformational leadership, and firm performance in high-technology start-up and established firm contexts. Data were collected from 105 (i.e., 49 start-up and 56 established) firms. Results showed that CEO positive psychological traits positively related to transformational leadership ratings. Furthermore, transformational leadership related more strongly to firm performance in start-up than in established firm contexts. Finally, transformational leadership fully mediated the relationship between leader positive psychological traits and firm performance. Implications for theory and practice are discussed.

Title: Career-related network building behaviors, range social capital, and career outcomes
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We studied 459 social servants to determine how their career network building behaviors were related to their social capital, and how this affected their speed of promotion within their organizational hierarchy. Results suggest that greater use of network building behaviors leads to greater range social capital, which leads to faster promotion. Factor analysis suggested two main strategies for network building behaviors: networking within structured groups organized around activities (foci) and informal unstructured networking. Informal unstructured networking behaviors were related to greater range social capital and faster promotion, while structured foci networking behaviors were unrelated.

Title: Shared leadership in dispersed innovation teams: Mutual influence and proactive followership
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Leading dispersed innovation teams poses critical challenges with team members separated and the tasks dynamic and complex. 'Hands-on' influence attempts by vertical formal or informal team leaders are largely ineffective in this context, leading to a naturally arising leadership vacuum in dispersed innovation teams. Focusing on this domain, we briefly review the literature on alternatives to vertical leadership (e.g., emergent leadership, self-leadership, shared leadership). Based on this analysis, we adapt and extend the concept of shared leadership to the context of dispersed innovation teams. Specifically, we conceptualize shared leadership in this context as consisting of two distinct elements, i.e., proactive followership and mutual influence. Both are cross-level constructs. Proactive followership entails the individual seeking information from the team and reacting to influences from it, while mutual influence entails the individual exerting influence on the team. We develop propositions linking these two variables as well as their interaction term to the performance of dispersed innovation teams. Moreover, we discuss the role of the formal team leader in the context of shared leadership. As such, this paper pertains to this year's conference theme (Doing well by doing good) in that a more participatory understanding of leadership helps a larger group of employees (beyond just formal leaders) to more fully draw on their potentials and experience a more satisfying workplace.

Title: Social capital in organizations: Understanding the link to firm performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Four measures of organizational culture-involvement, consistency, mission, and adaptability-are used to test the hypothesis that the social capital of an organization has a long-term impact on financial performance. After reviewing the relevant literatures of the resource-based view, social capital, and organizational culture this study helps explain the conditions under which resources developed or acquired in one period have an impact on the strategic advantages of firms in subsequent periods. The results report the return-on-assets, sales growth, and the market-to-book ratio of 102 companies. Measures of organizational culture were selected at one point in time from 1997-2004 for these firms. Totaling 116,000 employees surveyed, the results suggest adaptability contributes the most to long-term financial performance followed by the dimension of involvement. This study contributes to the resource based view of the firm and the strategic importance of social capital in organizations.

Title: Substantive versus symbolic implementation of ISO 14001: The role of corporate headquarters

Abstract: Recent studies that suggest that the quality of implementation of certified environmental management systems such as ISO 14001 varies across certified firms have raised concerns about the usefulness of certifiable standards as mechanisms for firm self-regulation. Title: The determinants of success in R&D alliances
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: We analyze data from 397 firms in 142 R&D alliances to examine the determinants of success in R&D alliances. We find that benefits from alliance participation differ significantly across firms in the same alliance and that alliance execution factors are more important than initial conditions of alliance formation.

Title: A new measurement scale for employee engagement: Scale development, pilot test, and replication
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: Employee engagement has been used to describe the extent to which employees devote themselves and their full energies to work related endeavors. Although engagement is receiving much attention in the popular press, scholarly work has lagged behind. Conceptual and operational inconsistencies have plagued academic research, and current findings are somewhat equivocal. To facilitate the development of a coherent research stream, a thorough review of extant theoretical and empirical research was performed. Based on this review, a conceptual definition of work engagement as a situation-activated psychological state was proposed, and a new measurement scale was developed and tested.

Title: Building a competency-based mba from the ground UP: Curriculum design and program delivery
Source title: Academy of Management 2007 Annual Meeting: Doing Well by Doing Good, AOM 2007
Abstract: The last twenty years have witnessed two important cycles of criticism of management education, much of it valid. The first cycle of criticism (1985-1995) targeted the lack of balance between soft and hard skills and the belief that acquisition of functional knowledge alone does not guarantee that students, albeit successful in the classroom, can actually 'do' the job of management. Responsible management educators have sought a variety of responses to this particularly poignant criticism, and one of the most effective responses has been competency-based programs aimed at assuring that participants can take best management practices and transfer them into their everyday experiences. The second cycle (1995- 2005) centered on the claim that business schools have failed to teach students how to grapple with complex, qualitative issues faced by firms competing in global markets. Here, too, the challenge for many schools of business has been to include strategic integration and global managerial competencies in the new curriculum. One model of a competency-based MBA with curricular design that was implemented in 2000 in response to the first cycle of criticism and revised again 5 years later in response to the new cycle of criticism is described. Implications for programmatic and curriculum innovation are also examined.
